questions.text:
A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation. There is no family history of serious illness. She cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position. She can pick an object between her thumb and index finger but cannot feed herself using a spoon. She comes when called by name, is willing to play with a ball, and looks for it after being hidden. She cries if she does not see her parents in the same room as her. She babbles. She is at 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination including neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of her development?



Fine motor
Gross motor
Language
Social skills



A
Delayed
Normal
Delayed
Normal


B
Normal
Delayed
Normal
Delayed


C
Delayed
Normal
Normal
Delayed


D
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
Normal


E
Normal
Normal
Delayed
Delayed


F
Normal
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate social skills development (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) and delayed language development (i.e., only babbles). However, she cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position, which suggests delayed gross motor skills development. In addition, her fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp) is appropriate for her age.

B) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp), and delayed gross motor skills development (i.e., cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position). However, she only babbles, which suggests delayed language development. In addition, her social skills (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) are appropriate for her age.

C) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate rather than delayed social skills (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) and fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp). Additionally, she shows delayed rather than appropriate language (i.e., only babbles) and gross motor skills development (i.e., cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position).

D) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate social skills development (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) and delayed gross motor skills development (i.e., cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position). However, she only babbles, which suggests delayed language development. In addition, her fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp) is appropriate for her age.

E) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp) and delayed language development (i.e., only babbles). However, she cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position, which suggests delayed gross motor skills development. In addition, her social skills (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) are appropriate for her age.

F) CORRECT:

By the age of 12 months, most children can pull themselves to a stand, walk with support, and use specific sounds to refer to a particular person (e.g., call the mother “mama” and the father “dada”). This child only has the gross motor development and speech development of a 9-month-old (sitting without support, babbling). Her fine motor skills development (pincer grasp) and social development (e.g., willingness to engage in play by giving objects, looking for hidden objects, separation anxiety) are appropriate for a 13-month-old child. The ability to feed oneself with a spoon is only expected by the age of 2 years.

See “Developmental milestones in infancy” table.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy since. She can climb up and down the stairs and can pedal a tricycle. She uses a spoon to feed herself but cannot yet use a fork. She speaks in three-word sentences that most people can understand and says her first name when asked. She is selfish while playing with children of her age and often throws tantrums. She can put on her own shoes and socks. She does not tolerate separation from her parents. She is at 60th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination including neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of her development?



Gross motor
Fine motor
Language
Social skills



A
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
Normal


B
Normal
Delayed
Normal
Delayed


C
Delayed
Normal
Normal
Delayed


D
Normal
Normal
Delayed
Delayed


E
Normal
Delayed
Delayed
Normal


F
Delayed
Normal
Delayed
Normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) and delayed fine motor skill development (i.e., only feeding herself using a spoon). However, she has strong separation anxiety and selfish, self-centered behavior, both of which suggest delayed social development. In addition, her gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) is appropriate for a 3-year-old.

B) CORRECT:

This 3-year-old has appropriate language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) and gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes). By the age of 3 years, most children can also use a fork, engage in group play, share toys with other children, and have minimal separation anxiety (since they begin to develop a drive for independence). Therefore, this child has delayed fine motor skills and social development.

See “Developmental milestones in childhood” table.

C) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) and delayed social development (i.e., strong separation anxiety, self-centered behavior). However, she can only feed herself using a spoon, which suggests delayed fine motor skill development. In addition, her gross motor skills (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) are appropriate for a 3-year-old.

D) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) and delayed social development (i.e., strong separation anxiety, self-centered behavior). However, she can only feed herself using a spoon, which suggests delayed fine motor skill development. In addition, her language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) is appropriate for a 3-year-old.

E) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) and delayed fine motor skill development (i.e., only using a spoon to feed herself). However, she has strong separation anxiety and selfish, self-centered behavior, both of which suggest delayed social development. In addition, her language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) is appropriate for a 3-year-old.

F) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old child only has the fine motor skills and social development of a 2-year-old (using a spoon to feed herself, strong separation anxiety, selfish and self-centered behavior). Moreover, gross motor development and language development are not delayed.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at term, and pregnancy was complicated by prolonged labor. There is no family history of serious illness. He can sit upright without support and can roll over from the supine to the prone position. He cannot pull himself up to stand. His hands are fisted most of the time and he cannot yet hold his rattle when placed in the palm. He babbles. He cries if anyone apart from his parents holds him or plays with him. He touches his own reflection in the mirror. He is at the 40th percentile for head circumference, 30th percentile for length, and 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following developmental milestones is delayed in this infant?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This 6-month-old boy's inability to hold a toy when placed in the palm suggests delayed fine motor development. The delay of a milestone, especially in combination with a problematic history such as the complicated birth seen here, should prompt further evaluation.

See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Stranger anxiety and the recognition of familiar people set in at around 6 months of age and represent a normal stage of development. The fact that this boy appears uncomfortable when away from his parents is, therefore, not concerning at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

This boy babbles, which is appropriate for a 6-month-old child. Therefore, there is no indication of delayed language development.

D) INCORRECT:

This 6-month-old child meets the developmental milestones of being able to sit without support and roll over from the supine to the prone position. Therefore, there is no indication of delayed gross motor development.

E) INCORRECT:

This boy notices and touches his reflection, which is appropriate for a 6-month-old child. Therefore, there is no indication of delayed cognitive skills.
questions.hint: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends routine developmental surveillance for all children, which should include eliciting parental concerns, documenting developmental history across multiple visits, observing caregiver-child interactions, and the use of specific screening tests.

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and the neonatal period were uncomplicated. The infant was exclusively breastfed and received vitamin D supplementation. She can sit unsupported and can transfer objects from one hand to the other. She babbles and is uncomfortable around strangers. She is at 40th percentile for length and at 35th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to continuing breastfeeding, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Introduce solid foods and add vitamin B12
Introduce solid foods and continue vitamin D
Introduce solid food and cow milk

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D supplementation is recommended in infants < 12 months old who are exclusively breastfed. Nevertheless, the prevention of other nutritional deficiencies should also be addressed at 6 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Infants should be introduced to solid foods at approximately 6 months of age, as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. However, foods such as meat, fish, and eggs contain sufficient amounts of vitamin B12, so that supplementation is only necessary if the mother or the child are eating a strictly vegetarian or vegan diet.

C) CORRECT:

Introduction to solid foods is recommended for infants at 6 months of age (approximately) as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. Additionally, Vitamin D supplementation is recommended in infants < 12 months old who are exclusively breastfed from birth until meeting the recommended daily intake of vitamin D through diet.

The diet should be balanced, and excessive amounts of foods and drinks high in sugar (e.g., fruit juice) should be avoided to prevent childhood caries. Once a solid diet is initiated, parents should also ensure good oral hygiene (e.g., rubbing the infant's gum with a wet cloth or using pediatric toothbrushes).

D) INCORRECT:

Foods such as meat, fish, and eggs contain sufficient amounts of vitamin B12, so that supplementation is only necessary if the mother or the child are eating a strictly vegetarian or vegan diet.

E) INCORRECT:

Infants should be introduced to solid foods at ∼ 6 months of age, as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. However, solid food alone does not contain adequate amounts of all the nutrients required so that further supplementation is indicated in infants.

F) INCORRECT:

Infants should be introduced to solid foods at ∼ 6 months of age, as they otherwise start developing deficiencies in certain nutrients (e.g., protein, iron, zinc) that breast milk cannot sufficiently supply. However, cow milk should not be introduced until 1 year of age as it is poorly tolerated in infants and associated with iron-deficiency anemia and higher rates of blood in infant stool.

G) INCORRECT:

Cow milk should not be introduced until 1 year of age as it is poorly tolerated in infants and associated with iron-deficiency anemia and higher rates of blood in infant stool.
questions.hint: Mature breast milk is composed of proteins, lactose, oligosaccharides, fats, minerals, trace elements, and vitamins, as well as proteins and cells that provide passive immunity, and bifidobacteria that contribute to the infant's gut flora.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and was 48 cm (19 in) in length and weighed 3061 g (6 lb 12 oz); she is currently 60 cm (24 in) in length and weighs 7910 g (17 lb 7 oz). She can pull herself to a stand and walk with one hand held. She can throw a small ball at her mother and looks for it if someone hides it. She can pick up an object between her thumb and index fingers. She can wave 'bye-bye'. She can say 'mama', 'dada' and 'uh-oh'. She cries if left to play with a stranger alone. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely delayed in this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expected language skills in a 12-month-old child include waving goodbye and using sounds to specifically refer to a particular person (e.g., “mama” when referring to mother). Delayed language development is not present.

B) INCORRECT:

Gross motor skills expected in healthy 12-month-old children include being able to pull themselves to a stand and walk with support (e.g., holding hands), which this child can do.

C) CORRECT:

On average, a healthy child grows 2.5 cm (1 in) per month within the first 6 months of life, and 1.3 cm (0.5 in) per month between 6–12 months of age. At the age of 12 months, an infant should typically have tripled their birth weight and be approximately 1.5 times the size at birth. Normal growth in children is assessed with the help of standardized growth charts, which compare the child's height and weight to that of other children of the same sex and age.

D) INCORRECT:

Age-appropriate fine motor skills in a 12-month-old child include picking up an object between the thumb and index fingers (pincer grasp). This child shows adequate development of fine motor skills.

E) INCORRECT:

Normally developed social skills in a 12-month-old child include engaging in interactive games and looking for objects after they are hidden. This child shows adequate social skills.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother is concerned that she has been talking to an imaginary friend for 2 months. The child calls her friend 'Lucy' and says “Lucy is my best friend”. The child has multiple conversations and plays with 'Lucy' throughout the day. The girl attends preschool regularly. She can hold a pencil between the first two fingers and the thumb, tells stories, and can hop on one foot. Her maternal uncle has schizophrenia. Her parents are currently divorcing. The child's father has a history of illicit drug use. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is concerned about whether the child is acting out because of the divorce. Which of the following is the most appropriate next best step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A number of drugs such as cocaine, ecstasy, amphetamines, lysergic acid diethylamide, and phencyclidine have been associated with hallucinations in children (e.g., following accidental ingestion). Since this girl's father has a history of drug abuse, unintentional contact with these substances should be considered. However, symptoms would typically have an acute onset, would not last for two months as in this girl, and would be different in character (e.g., perception of unusual colors).

B) INCORRECT:

Intracranial neoplasms can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including hallucinations. However, hallucinations as a primary symptom in the absence of other signs of a tumor, such as focal symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure, are very rare.

C) INCORRECT:

Child Protective Services (CPS) should be informed if there are signs of abuse or neglect of a minor. Signs of abuse and neglect can be subtle and history findings of parental drug use should certainly raise concern for the child's well-being. Although patients, particularly following sexual abuse, can develop hallucinations, these hallucinations commonly cause distress rather than comfort as in this patient. Additionally, this patient's age-appropriate milestones, the absence of signs of physical abuse, and the fact that she attends preschool regularly make child maltreatment less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A psychiatric consult would be indicated if an underlying psychiatric condition was suspected. While a variety of psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia or posttraumatic stress disorder can present with hallucinations, they are rare during childhood and more commonly associated with negative hallucinations (e.g., cause fear or distress). Additionally, unlike this girl, patients often show signs of abnormal development (e.g., delayed milestones).

E) INCORRECT:

Risperidone therapy would be indicated in a child with schizophrenia. Although children with schizophrenia typically also have hallucinations that last longer than one month and this child has a family history of schizophrenia, the condition is very rare in children, especially before puberty. Further, patients have to present with additional symptoms (e.g., delusions, disorganized behavior or speech, diminished emotions) and a decreased level of functioning in order to meet the DSM-5 criteria for schizophrenia.

F) CORRECT:

Imaginary friends are relatively common in preschoolers such as this girl and occur as part of normal development. Children typically get along with these friends (e.g., consider them “their best friend”) and the imaginary figures do not cause any distress or impaired functioning. Parents should be reassured. Further evaluation is only indicated if the imaginary friends persist beyond early school age, or if the child's general behavior or development changes.

Stress factors such as the parent's divorce can cause various behavioral responses in different age groups. Preschoolers such as this girl often display magical thinking and may believe that their actions caused the divorce. They can subsequently develop unusual or odd behaviors in the hope of reconciling their parents. Parents should be advised to reassure the child that their actions had no influence on the decision to get a divorce. A counselor can assist if problems persist.
questions.hint: This patient's gross motor (hops on one foot), fine motor (tripod pencil grasp), and language (tells stories) developmental milestones are all appropriate for her age.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He can walk alone and run. He feeds himself with a spoon and can drink from a cup. He can scribble. He babbles and says “mama”. He points to show objects in which he has interest. He is at 40th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Speech therapy is indicated in children with a lacking progression of language skills, inability to pronounce certain sounds (dyslalia), or with speech disorders like stuttering. Delayed or impaired development of language skills can result from learning disabilities, intellectual disabilities, or neurodevelopmental conditions like autism spectrum disorder. While this child may benefit from speech therapy later, the underlying cause of delayed acquisition of language skills should be determined first.

B) CORRECT:

This 18-month-old patient presents with normal cognitive, motor, and self-care developmental milestones, but delayed language development since he is not able to say other words other than “mama”; at the age of 18 months, children are expected to say at least 3 specific words in addition to mama/dada. Delayed acquisition of language skills can be caused by hearing impairment, learning disabilities, intellectual disabilities, neurological conditions, and neurodevelopmental conditions like autism spectrum disorder. In the absence of general developmental delay, neurological deficits, or abnormal behavior, the most likely underlying cause is hearing impairment. Therefore, audiology evaluation is the next best step in management.

Routine screening for hearing loss is performed at birth and during well-child examinations at ages 4, 5, 6, 8, and 10 years. Because audiology evaluation is not part of the well-child examination at 18 months of age, particular attention should be paid to signs indicative of hearing impairment in the patient's history.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy in children may be indicated for injury recovery, as adjunctive therapy in children with conditions such as cerebral palsy and Duchenne muscular dystrophy, or for children with neurodevelopmental delays. Since this child shows adequate motor development for his age, physical therapy is not needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing may be used to support the diagnosis of Rett syndrome, which commonly manifests with verbal disability. Since Rett syndrome almost exclusively affects girls and manifests with progressive loss of previously acquired cognitive abilities, it is an unlikely cause of this boy's delayed language development.

E) INCORRECT:

Since testing that requires reading and naming of letters or symbols cannot be performed in infants and toddlers, this age group's visual acuity is instead tested via the child's ability to fixate an object and track it with its eyes. Visual acuity testing is routinely performed at well-child examinations from 1 month to 4 years of age. As this child has no history of visual impairment, there is no indication for specific assessment of visual acuity beyond the routine check-up.

F) INCORRECT:

The cover-uncover test is a diagnostic test used in the assessment of strabismus. Heterophoria can be detected by covering one eye for 1–2 seconds and observing that eye for refixation movement after being uncovered. Although latent strabismus may not always be clinically apparent and could have remained undetected in this child, it would not cause the developmental delay seen in this child.
questions.hint: An 18-month-old child should be able to say several single words.

questions.text: During the selection of subjects for a study on infantile vitamin deficiencies, a child is examined by the lead investigator. She is at the 75th percentile for head circumference and the 80th percentile for length and weight. She can lift her head up when in a prone position, but cannot roll over from a prone position. Her eyes follow objects without crossing the midline. She coos and makes gurgling sounds. When the investigator strokes the sole of her foot, her big toe curls upward and there is fanning of her other toes. She makes a stepping motion when she is held upright and her feet are in contact with the examination table. Which of the following additional skills or behaviors would be expected in a healthy patient of this developmental age?

choices.text: Responds to calling of own name
Cries when separated from her mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infants reach out for visible objects at about 6 months of age. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months; at this developmental age, infants have their hands fisted most of the time, occasionally opening them for short periods of time.

B) INCORRECT:

Responding to calling of their own names usually occurs around the age of 9 months in normally developing infants. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months and is less likely to have a significant response to verbal stimuli and/or calling of her own name.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants go through a normal developmental phase of separation anxiety at around the age of 9 months, which is characterized by excessive clinging to the main parental figure. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months and is unlikely to start crying when separated from her mother.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants gain the ability to roll over from supine to prone position at the age of 6 months. This infant has a milestone development consistent with the age of 2 months and is unlikely to be able to roll over from her back at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Healthy 2-month-old infants typically start to recognize caregivers and exhibit a social smile.
questions.hint: This patient has a developmental age of 2 months based on her motor milestones (can lift her head when in the prone position, follows objects without crossing the midline), speech milestones (coos, makes gurgling sounds), and the presence of a stepping reflex.

questions.text: A young girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is able to follow simple 2-step commands, such as “close your eyes, then stick out your tongue,” and half of her speech is understandable. She can say 2-word phrases and is able to name many parts of the body. Assuming normal development, which of the following milestones are expected in a patient this age?

choices.text: Holds a pencil between the first two fingers and the thumb

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Copying a circle when demonstrated is a cognitive skill expected at around 3 years of age. Cognitive skills expected at 2 years of age include using complex toys (e.g., switches), and playing with more than one toy at a time.

B) INCORRECT:

Separation anxiety usually resolves by the age of 3 years, when children willingly spend time away from their parents. At 2 years of age, and, assuming normal development, children are expected to still show signs of separation anxiety.

C) CORRECT:

Kicking a ball independently is a gross motor skill expected at around 2 years of age. Other gross motor skills expected around this age include running and independently climbing stairs with both feet on each step. The fine motor skill expected for children at 2 years of age is to be able to feed themselves with a spoon. Cognitive skills expected at 2 years of age include using complex toys (e.g., switches), and playing with more than one toy at a time. See “Developmental milestones in childhood” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Fastening buttons is a fine motor skill expected at around 5 years of age. The fine motor skill expected for children at 2 years of age is to be able to feed themselves with a spoon.

E) INCORRECT:

Hopping on one foot is a gross motor skill expected at around 5 years of age.

F) INCORRECT:

Tripod pencil grasping is a fine motor skill expected at around 4 years of age. The fine motor skill expected for children at 2 years of age is to be able to feed themselves with a spoon.
questions.hint: This patient's speech milestones are consistent with a developmental age of 2 years: approx. 50% of speech is understandable, use of 2-word phrases, and able to name multiple body parts.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of concerns about his behavior during the past year. His parents report that he often fails to answer when they call him and has regular unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming. At kindergarten, he can follow and participate in group activities but does not follow his teacher's instructions when these are given to him directly. He is otherwise cheerful and maintains eye contact when spoken to but does not respond when engaged in play. He gets along well with friends and family. He started walking at the age of 11 months and can speak in two-word phrases. He often mispronounces words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Selective mutism is a response to intense anxiety that may appear oppositional and often presents with social phobia. This patient often fails to respond when called and does not follow instructions consistently, but he does not fail to speak in any specific setting, nor does he show signs of anxiety in social situations.

B) CORRECT:

Undetected hearing impairment in children can cause delays in speech, language, and cognitive development. This patient's presentation with apparent inattentiveness and difficulty following directions when directly spoken to, delayed language development (at 4 years, he should be able to speak in at least 4-word sentences), mispronunciation of words (due to poor speech discrimination), and symptoms of frustration (apparently unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming) warrants a thorough evaluation for hearing impairment.

Routine screening for hearing loss in children is recommended for newborns and then periodically throughout childhood. Hearing tests should also be performed in all children with behavioral problems.

C) INCORRECT:

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) may also manifest with problems at home and school/kindergarten, difficulties of following orders/instructions, and frequent outbursts (e.g., unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming). However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of ODD such as excessive arguing, revenge-seeking behavior, and aggression towards figures of authority (e.g., teachers, parents). Instead, he presents with delayed language development, which would be atypical for ODD.

D) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) can manifest with impaired language development and deficits in social interaction and communication at home and in school, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of ASD such as poor eye contact and repetitive, stereotyped patterns of behavior. Instead, he presents with features of well-adjusted social and emotional behavior (e.g., getting along with friends and family, participating in group activities), which make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) can manifest with symptoms of inattention and impulsivity as seen in this patient (i.e., unprovoked episodes of crying and screaming, not responding when directly spoken to). However, delayed language development is atypical for ADHD and makes a different diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Specific learning disorders (e.g., dyslexia, dyscalculia, impairment of written expression) typically manifest with poor performance at school, failure to follow instructions, and difficulties in completing tasks. However, this patient only shows impaired attention when directly spoken to and delayed language development (only uses two-word phrases and often mispronounces words), which is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with inattention and difficulty following directions when directly spoken to for more than 6 months that severely impairs his language development and affects his behavior as well as social interaction. Such behavior is not age-appropriate and requires full evaluation by a doctor.
questions.hint: This patient's condition can be congenital or acquired.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old son to his pediatrician because he is having tantrums. The boy has no history of serious illness and is on track with developmental milestones. His mother recently returned to work 2 weeks ago. She explains that, since then, her son has had a tantrum roughly every other morning, usually when she is getting him dressed or dropping him off at daycare. He cries loudly for about 5 minutes, saying that he does not want to go to daycare while thrashing his arms and legs. According to the daycare staff, he is well-behaved during the day. In the evenings, he has tantrums about twice per week, typically when he is told he must finish his dinner or that it is time for bed. These tantrums have been occurring for about 6 months. The mother is concerned her son may have a behavioral disorder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the boy's behavior?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder is characterized by persistent impairment in communication and social interaction and restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior. However, the daycare center reports that the child engages in normal group play and as such autism spectrum disorder cannot be diagnosed at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Conduct disorder is characterized by a repetitive and persistent pattern of disruptive behavior for ≥ 12 months that violates the basic rights of others or age-appropriate societal norms or rules. This child does not display any patterns that are inappropriate for his age.

C) CORRECT:

Normal development is simply the absence of any diagnosable disorder. Temper tantrums and defiant behavior are normal to a certain extent in children aged 1–3 years, as long as they neither impair normal functioning during the day nor violate age-appropriate norms. If this child were to display consistent and excessive physical aggression towards his parents, or an irritable and angry mood throughout the entire day, there would be cause for concern. But as the daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved throughout the day, the tantrums are most likely a normal part of the child's development.

D) INCORRECT:

Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by anger, irritable mood, and defiant behavior towards figures of authority lasting ≥ 6 months. These behaviors must impair normal daily functioning. However, this child does not display these behaviors, as the daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved during the day.

E) INCORRECT:

There are many criteria used to assess the level of inattention and hyperactivity and to diagnose ADHD. One of the most important criteria is that both inattention and hyperactivity must be severe enough to interfere with normal daily functioning. The daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved during the day, which means that normal functioning cannot be considered impaired, and as such ADHD cannot be diagnosed at this point.

F) INCORRECT:

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is characterized by extreme irritability, anger, and severe recurrent outbursts of temper (verbal or behavioral) for ≥ 12 months that also impair normal daily functioning. However, as the daycare center reports that the child is well-behaved during the day, normal functioning cannot be seen as impaired, and as such disruptive mood dysregulation disorder cannot be diagnosed at this point.
questions.hint: The most important factor in differentiating normal behavior from a psychiatric disorder is ascertaining whether or not the behavior (e.g., tantrums, irritability) impairs normal, daily functioning and violates age-appropriate norms.

questions.text: Four-month-old twins are brought to the physician for a well-child examination. They were born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and have been healthy since. The birth weight of the first infant was 2606 g (6 lb 3 oz); his current weight is 6600 g (14 lb 9 oz) and he is at the 30th percentile. The birth weight of the second infant was 2580 g (5 lb 11oz); her current weight is 6500 g (14 lb 5 oz) and she is at the 25th percentile. Both of the twins can raise their head and chest in the prone position, reach for objects, localize sounds, and smile at sounds and sights. Two weeks ago, the female twin started propping herself up on her hands when prone. The mother expresses concern because the other twin is still unable to do so. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "There is no reason for concern, but I will order blood tests to rule out a genetic disorder."
"I will refer you to a developmental pediatrician for further assessment."
"We will set up examinations at shorter intervals until both children have achieved the same milestones."
"I will order a detailed neurological assessment to further investigate your child's developmental delay."
"There is no need to worry because differences between twins reaching milestones are normal."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Further evaluation including reviewing the newborn screening test and assessing for a genetic disorder would be warranted if the twin who cannot yet prop himself up failed to obtain the milestone by the time of his next well-child examination. At this time, there is no reason to pursue further testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Further evaluation including a referral to a developmental pediatrician would be warranted if the twin who cannot yet prop himself up failed to obtain the milestone by the time of his next well-child examination. At this time, there is no reason for a referral.

C) INCORRECT:

The twin who is unable to prop himself up will need to be reassessed at his next well-child examination, but there is no need to set up examinations at shorter intervals. Frequent examinations are only required for infants with certain risk factors (e.g., perinatal complications, genetic disorders, history of living in impoverished conditions, and/or domestic violence in the family), which are not present here.

D) INCORRECT:

The twin who is unable to prop himself up would need a detailed neurological assessment only if he has red flags (e.g., hypertonia/hypotonia, dysmorphism, failure to thrive, positive newborn screening). Since he does not have any such red flags a detailed neurological assessment is not indicated at this time; he only needs to be reassessed at his next well-child examination. If he has failed to obtain the milestone by then, a detailed neurological examination will be performed.

E) CORRECT:

Developmental milestones are based on the mean age at which children can perform a particular task. Individual differences in the age at which some developmental milestones are achieved are normal. The mean age at which infants attain the ability to prop themselves up with their hands while prone is 6 months. Therefore, the mother of these 4-month-old twins should be reassured, while the children should be reevaluated during the next well-child visit at 6 months of age. A developmental delay should be suspected if a particular milestone does not occur by the expected age.
questions.hint: Twins, like all other children, develop at different speeds, and each twin should be evaluated separately for any delays in obtaining milestones.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents report that she has been crying excessively since the last visit and are concerned that she is not well. Their babysitter has told them that she does not stop crying even with feeding or burping. They say that she used to be calm when she was left alone, but over the past week, she starts to cry whenever they leave the room. She was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age. Her parents have gradually introduced semisolid foods over the past three months. She is at the 75th percentile for height and weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she turns her head when her name is called. She coos “ma” and “da.” She crawls on the examination table, is able to independently get into a seated position, and passes a teddy from one hand to the other. She can be pulled up to stand but cannot stand without support. Plantar reflex is present bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is soft. She begins to cry when the physician picks her up. The remainder of the examination does not show any abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Separation anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety of separation from major attachment figures such as the parents and usually develops during childhood. Although this infant presents with symptoms of separation anxiety (e.g., starts to cry when her parents leave the room), the diagnosis of separation anxiety disorder cannot be established at this age.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive attachment disorder manifests with an inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior towards caretakers without seeking comfort when distressed. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures, which is not consistent with reactive attachment disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) usually manifests with detachment and inability or difficulty to form relationships. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures. Moreover, patients with ASD typically present with other findings such as abnormal language development and stereotypical patterns of behavior (e.g., hand flapping, adverse response to sounds), none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Infantile colic manifests with episodes of crying in otherwise healthy and thriving infants, which is seen here. However, crying in infantile colic is not associated with the absence of attachment figures, or the presence of strangers. Moreover, infantile colic typically resolves spontaneously by 3–4 months of age.

E) CORRECT:

This 9-month-old child presents with milestones that are appropriate for her age. Her crying pattern is consistent with stranger anxiety (crying when picked up by strangers) and separation anxiety (crying when her parents leave the room), both of which are typical and normal social behaviors in children of this age. See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

F) INCORRECT:

This infant shows no signs or symptoms suggestive of physical child abuse (e.g., injuries at different stages of healing). Infants who are subject to sexual child abuse may present with normal physical examination findings or with findings restricted to genital and anal areas, which can easily be overseen. Sexual child abuse should be considered in children with recurrent urinary tract infections and behavioral changes. This patient's presentation, however, is not suggestive of sexual child abuse or other types of child abuse (e.g., child neglect).
questions.hint: This 9-month old child presents with the appropriate gross motor skills (able to independently get into a seated position), fine motor skills (transfers objects from one hand to the other), and language milestones (cooing “ma” and “da”) for her age. Plantar reflex usually disappears around 12 months of age.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born by cesarean delivery at 36 weeks’ gestation because of bleeding due to placenta previa. There is no family history of serious illness. She can prop herself up on her hands when in a prone position and rolls from front to back. When placed in a seated position, she leans on her hands to support herself. She can grasp her toy rattle with her index finger and thumb and can transfer it from one hand to the other. She babbles “mama” and “dada.” She cries if anyone apart from her parents holds her or plays with her. She laughs when her parents play peek-a-boo and orients to her name. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 55th percentile for head circumference, 40th percentile for length, and 45th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following developmental milestones is delayed in this infant?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient orients to her name, which is an example of appropriate cognitive development in a 9-month-old child.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient transfers objects from one hand to the other and uses the pincer grasp (pinches objects between the tips of the index finger and the thumb). These abilities are examples of appropriate fine motor skill development in a 9-month-old child.

C) CORRECT:

By the age of 9 months, a child should be able to independently get into a seated position and sit without support. This child is only able to prop herself up on her hands when in a prone position, roll from front to back, and sit in a tripod position when placed in a seated position, all of which reflect the gross motor skills of a 6-month-old child. See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

The delay of a milestone, especially in combination with a problematic history, such as the complicated preterm birth of this patient, should prompt further evaluation. Since developmental milestones are not a precise tool for measuring pediatric development, the delay of a milestone should prompt further evaluation, e.g., using standardized developmental screening tests such as the Denver Developmental Screening Test II. If these tests confirm the presence of developmental delay, the underlying causes should be investigated and early intervention initiated.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient cries when someone unfamiliar holds her or plays with her, which are signs of stranger anxiety and separation anxiety. These behaviors are examples of appropriate social development in a 9-month-old child and are, therefore, not concerning at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient babbles disyllabic words (“mama”, “dada”), which is an example of appropriate language development in a 9-month-old child.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of irritability, drooling, and soft stools for the past 3 days. He has been sleeping poorly because he frequently wakes up crying, and breastfeeding does not always help to calm him. Yesterday, the mother noticed that he grabbed his right ear repeatedly and that he “felt a bit hotter than usual.” He is otherwise healthy and has been meeting all of his developmental milestones. He was exclusively breastfed until 6 months of age, when solid foods were introduced to his diet. He usually has a bowel movement 1–3 times per day. He has had no difficulty voiding. His only medication is a vitamin D supplement. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 40th percentile for height and at the 45th percentile for weight. He is alert and fully oriented. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a crying infant. He is drooling and calms when a plastic toy is put in his mouth. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. His diaper contains soft yellow-brown stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Give baby a chilled rubber ring
Obtain complete blood count and stool culture
Let baby chew on clean washcloth dipped in sugar-water

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduled acetaminophen administration is indicated for infants with teething syndrome that cannot be managed with other methods. The treatment of teething is primarily palliative and nonpharmacologic methods should first be attempted before systemic analgesia is used.

B) CORRECT:

Teething is best treated by allowing the baby to chew on a chilled (not frozen) teething device or applying pressure to the baby's gum using clean fingers or wet gauze. The teething device should be in one piece to prevent choking or injury to the mouth and should not be dipped in sugary substances to avoid causing dental caries. Systemic analgesics (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen) are reserved for teething pain not effectively managed with conservative interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

Topic anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine, benzocaine) should be avoided in infants due to the high risk of intoxication and serious adverse reactions. For example, the use of benzocaine sprays or gels has been associated with inducing life-threatening methemoglobinemia in infants.

D) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies and stool cultures are indicated for infectious workup of diarrheal illness. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of teething, and diarrhea can occur as a part of teething syndrome, so further workup is unnecessary in the absence of other signs of infection (i.e., normal abdominal examination, appropriate stool color, normal vital signs).

E) INCORRECT:

Allowing babies to chew on a washcloth is appropriate for the treatment of teething syndrome, but dipping teething devices in sugary water should be avoided because this increases the risk of dental caries.
questions.hint: The first eruption of teeth in babies typically occurs at 6–12 months of age and can be associated with irritability, subfebrile temperatures, drooling, ear pulling, and soft stools, the combination of which is sometimes referred to as teething syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy since. There is no family history of serious illness. She can write her own name, is able to tie a knot, and can hop on one foot. Her father says that she has started watching television and often plays with his cell phone. She attends school regularly. She has been at the 50th percentile for both height and weight for the last 2 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The father is concerned about the effects of media exposure on his child. The physician recommends limiting screen time to approximately 1 hour daily, content monitoring by parents, and the use of a family media plan with child safety filters. At this visit, it is most appropriate for the physician to provide the father with which of the following additional health maintenance recommendations regarding the child?

choices.text: Prepare separate meals for the child and fix the portion sizes of each meal
Ensure that the child is wearing a helmet and knee pads when cycling
Include a compulsory daytime nap for the child in her daily routine
Set expectations for child's academic performance at school
Use a rear-facing seat for the child when she is in a car

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

By 1 year of age, children that are otherwise well no longer require separate food and should be eating the same meals as the parents. Healthy children can be trusted to decide how much to eat, so portion size restriction is not usually required.

B) CORRECT:

Anticipatory guidance to parents of preschoolers and school-age children consists of recommendations regarding nutrition, physical development (e.g., being physically active for at least 60 minutes daily), personal hygiene (e.g., brush twice and floss once a day), sleep, media use, cognitive and social development, techniques for behavioral modification (e.g., positive reinforcement for good behavior), and, most importantly, child safety. Unintentional injury is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children over 1 year of age. Children should always wear protective gear when performing high-risk activities (e.g., cycling, climbing) and use a child safety seat appropriate for age and anthropometry when riding in a car. At 5–6 years of age, the child should be taught safe street habits and, if possible, how to swim. Children under 6 years of age should be supervised continuously during play; for children aged 6–8 years, supervision is necessary when near bodies of water or when engaged in risky activities. At home, fire alarms should be installed, fire escape plans implemented, firearms removed or stored under lock-and-key, and potentially harmful household products and tools kept out of reach.

Children should be encouraged to tell their parents if they are being bullied or face other problems at school. To minimize the likelihood of abuse, children should also be told that no adults should ever ask them to keep a secret from their parents or express interest in the child’s private parts.

C) INCORRECT:

While a majority of toddlers take daytime naps, only approx. 5% of children still do so by 6 years of age. At this age, daytime naps are not necessary and should not be forced, as they can delay sleep onset at night. The focus of guidance should be on establishing a routine for going to bed at night and sleeping. For children 6–12 years of age, 9–12 hours of sleep is recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

It is important for parents to be involved with their children’s schooling, and they should be available to help their children with schoolwork. However, instead of the parent setting expectations for academic performance, children should be encouraged to set their own achievable goals and ask for help as needed. Good behavior should be met with reinforcement (e.g., with praise, privileges) that is focused on actions rather than immutable traits (e.g., intelligence).

E) INCORRECT:

Children under 13 years of age should always ride in the back seat, and children below 4 years of age should use rear-facing seats. A forward-facing car seat should be used for children 4–8 years of age (or earlier if the child outgrows the rear-facing car seat). A booster seat should be used for children 8–12 years of age or as soon as the child outgrows the forward-facing car seat.
questions.hint: This guidance should also have been provided during the well-child visit at 3 years of age when toddlers can begin to perform the relevant activity.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. She reports that for almost a year, he has been episodically “acting out” by stomping his feet and screaming at home. She says that she sometimes scolds him during these episodes in an attempt to correct his behavior, but his tantrums have become worse and more frequent over time. According to his teachers at preschool, he is calm and plays cooperatively. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He can draw a square, hop on one foot, and brush his teeth. He can identify several colors and numbers and occasionally tells stories to his parents. He enjoys being read stories before bedtime, and he sleeps 11 hours every night and 1–2 hours during the day. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is worried that his behavior will continue when he starts kindergarten next year and asks if it would be appropriate to gently spank her son to discipline him. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for responding to the boy’s behavior?

choices.text: Take away the child's favorite toy after he has a tantrum
Restrict the child's daytime naps and put him to bed earlier in the evening
Ignore the child while he is having a tantrum
Explain to the child why his behavior is socially inappropriate
Offering the boy chocolate during a tantrum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Taking away the child's favorite toy after he has a tantrum is an example of negative punishment. Although punishment may be effective in older children and adolescents when coupled with rewards for good behavior, it is not effective for decreasing unwanted behavior in preschoolers. Moreover, while punishment may result in a temporary decrease in unwanted behavior, it does not typically lead to behavior extinction.

B) INCORRECT:

Children who get insufficient sleep can become cranky, which can contribute to temper tantrums. This child is getting sufficient sleep for his age (10–13 hours per day including naps). Furthermore, daytime napping is normal until 5–6 years of age and should not be restricted.

C) CORRECT:

Ignoring the child (e.g., by putting them on time-out) is one of the most effective approaches for a preschooler who is having a temper tantrum. Although ignoring the child may initially result in a temporary increase in the behavior, this approach eventually leads to extinction by eliminating any positive reinforcement of the behavior. If using a time-out, the parent should briefly explain to the child that the time-out is related to their temper tantrum. No other communication (e.g., scolding, teaching) should take place during a time-out. Physical punishment is largely ineffective and strongly discouraged because it can cause physical harm. Some forms of physical punishment are considered child abuse under state and federal laws. Physical punishment can also have deleterious effects on the child's psychosocial development, e.g., by teaching them that violence is an appropriate means of conflict resolution.

While this is a developmentally normal behavior in preschoolers, health care providers should evaluate children with temper tantrums for conditions that can cause or contribute to tantrums (e.g., hearing and/or visual impairment, learning disabilities).

D) INCORRECT:

Explaining to the child why his behavior is socially inappropriate is useful in older children and adolescents. However, this technique has limited effectiveness in preschoolers. Explaining to a preschooler why a behavior is inappropriate may actually reinforce the behavior by giving them attention.

E) INCORRECT:

Offering the child chocolate during a tantrum is an example of positive reinforcement. Although this response might temporarily console the child, it is likely to inadvertently cause an increase in the unwanted behavior in the future. Parents should reward good behavior rather than reinforce unwanted behavior.
questions.hint: This child's behavior is consistent with temper tantrums, which are a common and developmentally normal behavior in children 2–5 years of age. Parents must respond to temper tantrums with age-appropriate measures.

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is exclusively breastfed and receives no medications. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. All routine immunizations are administered. Anticipatory guidance about feeding and development is given. At the end of the visit, the mother asks if she can continue using an oral pacifier for her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "There are no adverse effects associated with the use of pacifiers in early infancy, and they can be used up until 5 years of age."
"Avoid using oral pacifiers until 6 months of age as it compromises breastfeeding. After 6 months, it is ok to use a pacifier."
"Pacifiers are usually only effective in the first month of life. There are no major benefits associated with pacifier use after this age."
"Pacifier use has no benefit and is not recommended at any age."
"Continue using oral pacifiers until 6 months of age, especially at the beginning of bedtime and nap time."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pacifier use is associated with adverse effects, such as increased risk of otitis media (especially between 2–3 years of age), and dental malocclusion (especially between 2–4 years of age).

B) INCORRECT:

Although pacifiers should be avoided until breastfeeding is well established (∼ 1 month of age) to prevent difficulties, they are recommended thereafter. Additionally, pacifier use is associated with adverse effects in infants over 6 months of age, such as increased risk of otitis media.

C) INCORRECT:

Pacifier use is associated with certain benefits during a specific period of infancy. Moreover, pacifiers should be avoided before breastfeeding is well established, which usually happens within the first month of life.

D) INCORRECT:

Pacifier use is associated with certain benefits (e.g., lower risk of SIDS).

E) CORRECT:

Pacifier use is recommended in infants 1–6 months of age at the start of bedtime and nap time to prevent SIDS. Nevertheless, infants should not be forced to use a pacifier, and it is not necessary to replace the pacifier if it falls out during sleep because the protective effect persists. To prevent difficulties, pacifiers should be introduced only after breastfeeding is well established. Pacifier use should be limited after 6 months of age to reduce the risk of otitis media and actively discouraged at approximately 2 years of age to prevent adverse dental effects (e.g., dental malocclusion).

Other protective factors for SIDS include a supine sleeping position, a safe sleeping environment and location (e.g., firm surface, no soft objects, cosleeping without bed-sharing), exclusive breastfeeding until 4–6 months of age, and routine immunizations.
questions.hint: Correct pacifier use can lower the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

questions.text: Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in an 18-month-old girl who is not yet speaking and does not respond to her parents' instructions or to her name being called but whose nonverbal communication, social interactions, and motor development are all otherwise normal?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Most 18-month-old children have a vocabulary of 10 to 20 words and will respond to their parents when called or spoken to. A child who does not meet these milestones but otherwise has normal social interactions and nonverbal communication skills should be evaluated for profound hearing impairment.

Early symptoms of profound hearing impairment include lack of startle to noises, lack of response to a parent’s voice, lack of response to one's name, and lack of speech.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an 18-month-old child who does not respond to her parents' voices but has otherwise normal social interactions and normal nonverbal communication skills is hearing impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with developmental language disorder have speech delays but will typically turn when their name is called and respond to simple commands.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with attachment disorder often have delays in cognition and language, and they do not have normal interactions and social relationship with parents.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with Rett syndrome develop normally until about 18 months of age, when they begin to regress in milestones and develop stereotypic hand movements and deceleration in head growth.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with autism spectrum disorder might have speech delays, but they also have deficits in social interactions, shared interests, nonverbal communication, relationship development, and imaginative play.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is seen for a well-child check. He has a history of well-controlled asthma and mild eczema but has been healthy, and his parents have no concerns about his health and development.
Which one of the following milestones should this child be asked to demonstrate to assess for typical development?

choices.text: Grasp pencil between thumb and fingers
Copy a circle with a crayon

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although motor and self-care abilities are in development at age 3, a child would not be expected to reliably pour liquid into a cup until age 4.

B) INCORRECT:

A child will typically move from grasping a writing instrument in their fist to holding it between their thumb and fingers by age 4. This milestone can be assessed together with the milestone of copying a circle (typical for age 3) or drawing a person with several body parts (typical for age 4).

C) INCORRECT:

Children typically learn to identify some colors (e.g., they are able to point to the blue ball) by age 2.5 years and then will learn to name several colors by the time they reach age 4.

D) CORRECT:

A 3-year-old child who has normal fine-motor development should be able to draw a circle, use a fork, and string beads on a string. Although some children may achieve skills earlier than expected, screening questions typically focus on those skills that are widely achieved by the given age.

Key learning point: Fine-motor developmental milestones for a 3-year-old child include using a fork, stringing beads on a string, and drawing a circle.

E) INCORRECT:

By 2.5 years, most children can jump with two feet, but they are not yet able to hop on one foot, a skill that children typically develop by age 5.

questions.text:
A 4-week-old girl who was born at full-term is seen for a well-child visit. Her parents express no concerns about her development. Review of her growth chart demonstrates steady growth along the 25th percentile for head circumference, length, and weight.
When placed supine on the examination table, she easily lifts her chin and turns her head. She follows faces, startles to voice and sound, and makes frequent throaty noises. Her hands remain fisted near her face.
Which one of the following developmental milestones is this infant most likely to reach next?

choices.text: Turning her head in the direction of someone’s voice

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This infant is developing at a normal pace. At one month of age, she can follow a face, startle to voice and sound, and make frequent throaty noises. During the next 4 weeks, she is expected to begin to smile responsively, open and close her hands, and make smoother movements with her arms and legs.

Although infants and children will progress along the developmental milestones at slightly different speeds, it is important to monitor general progress along the expected trajectories, noting any major missed milestones or delays that should prompt further evaluation, referral to early intervention programs, or both.

Key learning point: An infant should have a social and reciprocal smile by the age of 2 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Grasping objects in one’s hands, giggling out loud, and turning one’s head in response to voice are milestones that infants typically reach by 4 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Grasping objects in one’s hands, giggling out loud, and turning one’s head in response to voice are milestones that infants typically reach by 4 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Grasping objects in one’s hands, giggling out loud, and turning one’s head in response to voice are milestones that infants typically reach by 4 months of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Vocalizing with cooing sounds develops by age 4 months, followed by squealing noises and ultimately babbling with consonant sounds over time.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy presents for a routine well-child evaluation. His birth history is unremarkable. He is exclusively breastfed and has been gaining weight appropriately.
Which one of the following skills would this patient most likely be able to demonstrate?

choices.text: Sitting in tripod position with his hands in front for support
Passing objects from one hand to the other
Raking up objects with four fingers
Grasping a toy when it is placed in his hand

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

By 6 months of age, a typical infant is able to roll from prone to supine, push up with straight arms when prone, and reach for a toy that they want.

B) INCORRECT:

Infants learn to sit by first sitting while having their trunk supported and then sitting steadily while supporting their weight on their hands (tripod sitting) around age 6 months, and ultimately sitting well without a need for support by age 9 months.

C) INCORRECT:

By 6 months of age, a typical infant is able to roll from prone to supine, push up with straight arms when prone, and reach for a toy that they want.

D) INCORRECT:

By 6 months of age, a typical infant is able to roll from prone to supine, push up with straight arms when prone, and reach for a toy that they want.

E) CORRECT:

At 4 months of age, a typical infant will be able to grasp a toy such as a rattle when it is presented to them, bring their fingers to their mouth, and support their weight on their elbows and forearms when prone.

Key learning point: A child with typical development should be able to bring their hands to their mouth and grasp objects when presented with them by the age of 4 months.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old male infant is brought in for a routine health maintenance visit. He was born at 38 weeks’ gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 33-year-old mother after an uneventful pregnancy. He was discharged from the newborn nursery at 2 days of life. At 4 days of life, he was breastfeeding and growing well.
His parents report that he has been well at home and that he coos but does not babble. He makes eye contact with them and smiles back at them but does not giggle.
His growth parameters and physical examination are normal. On neurologic examination, he smiles reciprocally and moves his arms and legs, opening his hands intermittently. While lying prone, he does not hold his head up.
Which one of the following assessments is most appropriate to share with this child’s parents?

choices.text: The child needs to be monitored closely for possible delay in social milestones
The child needs to be monitored closely for possible delay in cognitive milestones
The child needs to be monitored closely for possible delay in motor milestones
The child needs to be monitored closely for possible delay in emotional milestones

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This child is showing normal achievement of social, cognitive, and emotional milestones; therefore, additional monitoring of these skills is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

This child is showing normal achievement of social, cognitive, and emotional milestones; therefore, additional monitoring of these skills is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Infants develop at differing speeds, but they typically follow similar patterns of milestone acquisition over time. At each well-child visit, clinicians should elicit parental concerns about development and take a careful history of developmental progress in order to identify children who are at risk and might benefit from early intervention or further evaluation.

Most 2-month-old infants are able to hold their heads up for several seconds when lying prone and then lay their heads down without letting them drop. They may also be able to hold their heads up for longer periods and turn their heads side to side while prone. This child cannot hold his head up, so although he is moving his arms and legs and opening his hands normally, close monitoring of his gross motor skills is warranted, with consideration of referral to early intervention.

In addition to motor skills, 2-month-old infants should be reaching communication milestones such as turning to sounds and making sounds other than crying, and social and emotional milestones such as smiling back at a familiar person who smiles first. Infants do not typically giggle until closer to 4 months of age.

Key learning point: When lying prone, a 2-month-old child should be able to hold their head up for several seconds.

D) INCORRECT:

This child cannot hold his head up, so although he is moving his arms and legs and opening his hands normally, close monitoring of his gross motor skills is warranted, with consideration of referral to early intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

This child is showing normal achievement of social, cognitive, and emotional milestones; therefore, additional monitoring of these skills is not indicated.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old girl presents for a well-child visit. She is breastfed and is at the 75th percentile for weight and length and the 50th percentile for head circumference. She sleeps for 10 hours each night and takes one or two naps each day.
Which one of the following examination findings would indicate the need for further developmental evaluation of this infant?

choices.text: Lack of ability to transfer a toy from one hand to the other
Inability to roll supine to prone
Requiring trunk support to sit up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a 4-month-old infant will typically grasp for an object when it is presented to them, they do not develop the ability to transfer objects from one hand to the other until a few months later.

B) INCORRECT:

Children typically develop shyness around unfamiliar people (“stranger shyness”) around 9 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants do not typically begin to roll from supine to prone or respond to their name until closer to 6 months of age, and a child would not be considered delayed if they could not do these tasks at 4 months.

D) CORRECT:

Infants develop at differing speeds, following similar patterns of milestone acquisition over time. Each well-child visit provides an opportunity to elicit parental concerns about development. A careful history of developmental progress should be taken in order to identify children at risk who should be referred for early intervention or further evaluation.

A 4-month-old infant who is developing normally would be expected to have reached the following milestones:

• Gross motor: Sits steady when you are supporting their trunk and will not have head lag when pulled from a prone position to sitting
• Fine motor: Uses their arm to swing at toys, grasps a toy when it is placed in their hand, and spontaneously brings their hands to their mouth
• Social-emotional: Smiles spontaneously at pleasurable sights or sounds and chuckles
• Language: Turns their head toward the sound of a caregiver’s voice and makes sounds back to the caregiver

Infants typically develop a social smile by 2 months of age and by 4 months should smile spontaneously, especially at people, and may begin to chuckle and even laugh at pleasurable things.

Key learning point: A 4-month-old infant who witnesses a pleasurable sight or person should be able to smile spontaneously.

E) INCORRECT:

A 4-month-old infant who is developing normally would be expected to have reached the following milestones:

• Gross motor: Sits steady when you are supporting their trunk and will not have head lag when pulled from a prone position to sitting.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old girl presents for a well-child visit. Her parents have no concerns about her development. Review of her growth chart demonstrates steady growth along the 25th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference.
While on the examination table, the patient babbles, laughs, and bangs her hands on the table. She rolls front to back and back to front, and she sits in a tripod position with her hands placed in front of her. She cries when you approach.
Which one of the following additional skills would this patient most likely be able to demonstrate?

choices.text: Pick up a small item with three fingers and her thumb
Drop a cube into a cup

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 6-month-old child may have a four-finger raking grasp, but this will typically not transition to including the thumb until 9 to 12 months and then the thumb-finger pincer grasp after that.

B) CORRECT:

This infant exhibits age-appropriate language and social-emotional development; she babbles, laughs, and is wary of strangers. She also exhibits age-appropriate motor skills of head and truncal support with the ability to sit briefly, although she still needs to prop herself up on her hands. In the absence of any fine-motor development delays, an infant this age should also be able reach for an object in view.

Developmental surveillance screening should be incorporated into all routine well-child examinations. In addition, formal developmental screening, with use of validated screening tools, should be completed at the 9-month, 18-month, and 24- or 30-month well-child evaluations or at any time that routine surveillance identifies a red flag.

Key learning point: An infant should be able to reach for an object and sit in a tripod position by the age of 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

A 6-month-old child would not be expected to be able to drop an object into a cup, as this skill does not typically develop until 9 to 12 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

A 9-month-old child should be able to bang two cubes together. A 6-month-old child would not be considered delayed if she was unable to exhibit this fine-motor skill.

E) INCORRECT:

A 9-month-old child should be able to release objects intentionally. A 6-month-old child would not be considered delayed if she was unable to exhibit this fine-motor skill.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy is seen for a well-child visit. He can scribble on a blank piece of paper and use mature jargon when interacting with his mother. His mother states that he knows about 25 words, including three body parts. He is starting to try to use a spoon when eating.
His physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following additional skills would you expect this child to be able to perform?

choices.text: Turn the pages of a book one at a time when being read to

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Copying a circle is usually seen at 3 years of age.

B) CORRECT:

This child is developing normally and would be expected to be able to feed himself with his fingers.

At 18 months of age, other fine- and gross-motor developmental milestones include the ability to walk without holding onto anyone or anything, stack three to four blocks, scribble on a piece of paper, and try to use a spoon.

Development should be evaluated at every well-child visit, and formal developmental assessment using a validated screening tool should be done at the 9-month, 18-month, and 30-month (or 24-month) visits or whenever concerns are identified. Formal developmental assessment is appropriate if a child is not meeting their milestones.

Key learning point: Gross- and fine-motor developmental milestones for an 18-month-old child include the ability to feed himself with his fingers, scribble spontaneously, and walk without holding onto anyone or anything.

C) INCORRECT:

Unbuttoning clothing is typically seen at 4 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Kicking a ball is usually seen at 2 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Turning the pages of a book one at a time while being read to is usually seen at 2.5 years of age.

questions.text:
A one-month-old female infant who was born at term is brought in for a well-child check. She is breastfeeding well, is urinating six to eight times daily and stooling three times daily, and has gained 28 grams of weight per day since birth.
