Her weight, length, and head circumference are at the 50th percentile. The rest of her physical examination is within normal limits for her age.
Which one of the following developmental findings would be expected for a child of this age?

choices.text: She is able to push up on her elbows when prone and hold a rattle in her hand
She is able to lift her head up when prone and smile responsively
She is able to hold her hands together and make cooing noises
She is able to fix on faces and briefly follow them, and she calms down when picked up
She is able to bring her hands to her mouth and bat at toys

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

By the age of 4 months, most infants will be able to push up on their forearms or elbows when proneand hold rattles when they are given to them.

B) INCORRECT:

By the age of 2 months, most infants will be able to lift their heads up when prone, become alert to voices and sounds, and display reciprocal or social smiles.

C) INCORRECT:

By the age of 2 months, most infants will be able to hold their hands together and make noises that are not crying, which then progress to cooing by the age of 4 months.

D) CORRECT:

Developmental surveillance should occur at every well-child visit. Clinicians should elicit parental concerns, identify risk factors, make accurate observations, document a developmental history, and maintain an accurate record of the findings. In addition, standardized developmental screening tests should be conducted at 9, 18, and 24 or 30 months of age.

By the age of one month, an infant should be able fix on faces with their eyes and briefly follow them. They should also suck well, startle to sound, and calm down when picked up or spoken to.

By the age of 2 months, most infants will be able to lift their heads up when prone, hold their hands together, become alert to voices and sounds, display reciprocal or social smiles, and make noises that are not crying, which then progress to cooing by the age of 4 months.

By the age of 4 months, most infants will be able to push up on their forearms or elbows when prone, hold their heads steady when caregivers are holding them, hold rattles when they are given to them, bring their hands to their mouths, bat at toys, and make reciprocal sounds.

Key learning point: An infant who fixes on faces and calms down when picked up — but does not coo, babble, or show a reciprocal smile — is at the developmental age of one month.

E) INCORRECT:

By the age of 4 months, most infants will be able to bring their hands to their mouths and bat at toys.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy is brought in by his mother, who is concerned that he is not meeting all of his milestones as his older sibling did; in particular, she is worried about his ability to interact with others. He was born at 38 weeks without complications, is not taking any medications, and has no medical problems. His growth and physical examinations are normal.
Which one of the following developmental milestones should this patient be able to demonstrate?

choices.text: Cry when a stranger comes close

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Further social and emotional development over the subsequent months should include demonstrating stranger anxiety when confronted by unfamiliar faces.

B) INCORRECT:

Further social and emotional development over the subsequent months should include imitating speech sounds.

C) INCORRECT:

Further social and emotional development over the subsequent months should include waving bye-bye.

D) CORRECT:

At 6 months of age, a typically developing infant will recognize familiar faces, particularly those of their parents, and will respond to emotions in others. They should also smile and laugh and may also begin to recognize their name. Monitoring or further evaluation should be considered for a 6-month-old child who does not recognize and respond to their caregivers.

Further social and emotional development over the subsequent months should include demonstrating stranger anxiety when confronted by unfamiliar faces, playing peek-a-boo, imitating speech sounds, and waving bye-bye.

Key learning point: A social-cognitive milestone seen in a 6-month-old baby is recognition of parents.

E) INCORRECT:

Further social and emotional development over the subsequent months should include playing peek-a-boo.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old girl is noted to sit well while unsupported, pull to a stand, bang two cubes together, and hold her own bottle while feeding. She imitates sounds her mother makes and follows her mother’s pointed finger to a drawing on the wall.
Which one of the following other developmental milestones would this girl be expected to have achieved?

choices.text: Say a word other than “mama” or “dada”

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-motor skills for children at 9 months of age include using their fingers to rake food toward themselves and shaking or banging two objects together. Children are not expected to use a spoon until 18 to 24 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

A typical 9-month-old may say “dada” and “mama” indiscriminately but would not be expected to say 2 to 3 additional words until they are closer to 12 to 15 months.

C) CORRECT:

Children at 9 months of age can be expected to play and enjoy interactive social games such as peek-a-boo and possibly pat-a-cake. When their name is called, they should turn or respond in some way. They babble and will copy or imitate sounds made by others.

Each well-child visit should include an assessment of a child’s developmental milestones and periodic developmental screening using a standardized test.

Key learning point: The cognitive and behavioral milestones for a 9-month-old child include imitating sounds, responding to their name, and playing peek-a-boo.

D) INCORRECT:

From a gross-motor standpoint, a 9-month-old child would be expected to crawl or creep but not to walk independently.

E) INCORRECT:

From a gross-motor standpoint, a 9-month-old child would be expected to crawl or creep but not to throw a ball.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl is seen for a routine well-child evaluation. Her father expresses no concerns about her development. Review of her growth chart demonstrates steady growth along the 75th percentile for height, weight, and head circumference.
She says “mama,” “dada,” and “baby.” She can stand well and take a few independent steps. She holds a crayon and can dump things out of a container. As you leave the room, she waves bye-bye.
Which one of the following additional tasks should this patient be able to complete?

choices.text: Build a tower of three to four cubes
Pick up a small piece of food with a mature pincer grasp between thumb and pointer finger
Climb on and off a couch or chair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a 12-month-old child may hold a crayon, spontaneous scribbling is typically not observed until closer to 18 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

The ability to stack two small objects is not obtained until approximately 15 months of age, and building a tower of 4 to 6 objects does not come until later, when the child is older than 2 years of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Turning a doorknob or unscrewing a lid is a task for a 2.5-year-old child.

D) CORRECT:

In terms of motor development, a 12-month-old child should be able to pick up small pieces of food using a mature pincer grasp and drink from a cup without a lid when it is held for them.

Key learning point: In a typically developing child, the ability to pick up small pieces of food with a mature pincer grasp is seen at age 12 months.

E) INCORRECT:

The ability to climb on or off a couch or chair is not acquired until closer to 18 months of age.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy who was born full term presents for a routine well-child visit. His weight and height parameters are at the 50th and 25th percentiles, respectively.
On developmental assessment, you find that the boy can sit well without support and can pull to a stand. He is not yet cruising while holding onto furniture or taking steps independently. His mother reports that he babbles and says “mama” but nonspecifically and has no other words. He does not point or gesture but does respond to his name.
What is the most accurate assessment of this patient’s development?

choices.text: He is delayed at the level of an average 6-month-old infant
He is delayed at the level of an average 9-month-old infant
His gross-motor skills are as expected at 12 months, but he has features of a speech delay
He is on track and appropriate in his development
His language skills are as expected at 12 months, but he has features suggesting a delay in gross-motor development

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The average 6-month-old infant is not able to pull to a stand and does not recognize his own name.

B) CORRECT:

By 12 months of age, the average child can get into a sitting position unsupported, pull to stand, walk while holding onto furniture (cruise), exhibit a fine pincer grasp, gesture, and also use the words “mama” and “dada” specifically. Most 12-month-old children can also point with their index finger, but they may not point to specific objects to indicate desire until they are closer to 15 months.

This patient's language and gross-motor skills are both delayed to a level consistent with that of an average 9-month-old child: He can pull to a stand but cannot take independent steps or cruise, and he responds to his name but can only babble nonspecifically without words, gestures, or pointing.

Given that this child’s screening assessment revealed delays in more than one domain, the next steps are to conduct a comprehensive assessment to determine the cause and degree of developmental delay and to refer the patient to early developmental services. Because his language is affected, a hearing screening should also be considered.

Key learning point: A 12-month-old child who can pull to a stand but who cannot take steps while supported or cruise — and who responds to his name but only babbles nonspecifically without words, gestures, or pointing — has the developmental skills of a 9-month-old child.

C) INCORRECT:

By 12 months of age, the average child can get into a sitting position unsupported, pull to stand, walk while holding onto furniture (cruise), exhibit a fine pincer grasp, gesture, and also use the words “mama” and “dada” specifically. Most 12-month-old children can also point with their index finger, but they may not point to specific objects to indicate desire until they are closer to 15 months.

D) INCORRECT:

By 12 months of age, the average child can get into a sitting position unsupported, pull to stand, walk while holding onto furniture (cruise), exhibit a fine pincer grasp, gesture, and also use the words “mama” and “dada” specifically. Most 12-month-old children can also point with their index finger, but they may not point to specific objects to indicate desire until they are closer to 15 months.

E) INCORRECT:

By 12 months of age, the average child can get into a sitting position unsupported, pull to stand, walk while holding onto furniture (cruise), exhibit a fine pincer grasp, gesture, and also use the words “mama” and “dada” specifically. Most 12-month-old children can also point with their index finger, but they may not point to specific objects to indicate desire until they are closer to 15 months.

questions.text:
The parents of a 30-month-old girl express concern that she is not developing at the same pace as her peers in day care. She is able to fetch a familiar object when asked (without gesturing), use 10 single words, and bring objects to her parents to show them. She is not yet able to kick a ball, stack more than two blocks, follow two-step commands, or point to pictures in a book when asked.
What is the approximate developmental age of this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Most 9-month-old children are able to say “mama” and “dada” nonspecifically, use sounds to get attention, and recognize familiar people.

B) CORRECT:

This 30-month-old child is demonstrating developmental delay. Her pattern of abilities is most consistent with the developmental maturity of an 18-month-old child. The emergence of developmental skills varies considerably among children, so individual skills should be evaluated as part of the overall picture of development.

Formal assessment using a standardized developmental screening tool, such as the Ages and Stages questionnaire, is appropriate at the 9-month, 18-month, and 30-month (or 24-month) visits. The goal of this screening is to facilitate referral to early intervention programs and early childhood services for children who have developmental delays in any area.

Most 18-month-old children are able to follow a one-step command without gesturing such as fetching a familiar object when asked and are able to bring interesting objects to their caregivers to show them. They typically use at least three words other than “mama” or “dada.”

By 24 months of age, most children are able to stack more than two objects (typically up to four blocks), kick a ball, use significantly more words, combine two to four words in sentences, follow two-step commands, and point to objects in books when asked (e.g., “Where is the cow?”).

Key learning point: Having a vocabulary of about 50 words with the ability to put two words together is typically achieved by the age of 24 to 30 months.

C) INCORRECT:

By 12 months old, most children can use “mama” or “dada” more specifically and can play games such as pat-a-cake.

D) INCORRECT:

By 24 months of age, most children are able to stack more than two objects (typically up to four blocks), kick a ball, use significantly more words, combine two to four words in sentences, follow two-step commands, and point to objects in books when asked (e.g., “Where is the cow?”). Having a vocabulary of about 50 words with the ability to put two words together is typically achieved by the age of 24 to 30 months.

E) INCORRECT:

This 30-month-old child is demonstrating developmental delay. By 24 months of age, most children are able to stack more than two objects (typically up to four blocks), kick a ball, use significantly more words, combine two to four words in sentences, follow two-step commands, and point to objects in books when asked (e.g., “Where is the cow?”). Having a vocabulary of about 50 words with the ability to put two words together is typically achieved by the age of 24 to 30 months.

questions.text:
As you enter the room to see a 2-year-old male patient, his mother tells him to put down the ball and sit on the chair, and he obeys. The mother reports that he has a vocabulary of more than 50 words and that she can understand more than half of what he says. He has started using a spoon to feed himself and can walk down stairs while holding the handrail. When you ask him to throw the ball to you, he throws overhand.
His physical examination is normal. The mother completes the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers with a score of 0.
Which one of the following additional skills would you expect this patient to be able to perform?

choices.text: Walk up stairs while alternating feet

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Putting on loose clothes like pants or jackets is a motor milestone one would expect in a 3-year-old child, not a 2-year-old.

B) INCORRECT:

Although 2-year-old children can navigate stairs with both feet, alternating feet on stairs is a later skill developed by children at 3 to 4 years of age.

C) CORRECT:

Developmental milestones should be assessed at each well-child visit, with standardized developmental screening at 9, 18, and 24 or 30 months of age. Autism-specific screening using a tool such as the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT) is recommended at 18 and 24 months of age. An M-CHAT score of ≤2 is considered low risk.

Gross-motor milestones for a 2-year-old child include kicking a ball, throwing a ball overhand, and walking up stairs with both feet on each stair. Children at 2 years of age can also be expected to follow commands, use a spoon, try to use knobs on a toy, point to body parts, and put two words together spontaneously (not as a set phrase); speech should be more than 50% intelligible.

Key learning point: Kicking a ball is a milestone typically achieved by age 24 months (2 years).

D) INCORRECT:

Pedaling a tricycle is a motor milestone one would expect in a 3-year-old child, not a 2-year-old.

E) INCORRECT:

Copying a circle is a motor milestone one would expect in a 3-year-old child, not a 2-year-old.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is noted to be a very talkative child. His mother states that his vocabulary includes more words than she can count. He uses three-word sentences and refers to himself in the first person. Most people can understand approximately 75% of what he says. He likes to play house and help with chores. He can copy a circle, eat independently, pedal a tricycle, and jump with two feet.
Which one of the following additional activities will this patient most likely be able to perform?

choices.text: Hop on one foot two to three times

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Many children can catch a ball with stiff arms by age 3 but are unable to catch a bounced ball until age 4.

B) INCORRECT:

Most 3-year-old children can help dress themselves, but only later do they develop the skills to unbutton and then button clothing buttons.

C) CORRECT:

Developmental milestones vary by child but typically develop in an expected progression. It is important to ask about, and observe, developmental milestones at well-child visits in order to identify children who may need further evaluation or intervention.

In this case, the child is developing as expected. Typically, a 3-year-old child who demonstrates normal fine-motor and self-help skills should be able to draw a circle, take off their shoes, and eat independently. In the absence of any underlying gross-motor delay, they should also be able to jump with two feet, climb onto furniture, and pull on loose pants or a basic jacket. At this age, however, they would not be expected to hop, stand, or skip on one foot yet. In addition, they would not be expected to dress fully or to button or unbutton buttons.

Developmental surveillance should be incorporated into all health supervision visits and should include evaluation for parental concerns about development, identification of any potential biologic or environmental risk factors for developmental delay, and observation and documentation of developmental milestones.

Key learning point: In the absence of underlying delay, the ability to draw a circle and pull on loose pants is typically seen by 3 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

At this age they would not be expected to hop, stand, or skip on one foot yet.

E) INCORRECT:

At this age they would not be expected to hop, stand, or skip on one foot yet.

questions.text: Which one of the following tasks should a 4-year-old child be able to perform as evidence that their motor skills are developing normally?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Some 4-year-old children may be able to hop, but this skill may take until closer to age 5. Similarly, the ability to skip with two feet and to walk backward toe-to-heel are skills more commonly demonstrated by 5-year-old children, so an inability to do these tasks does not signal delayed development in a 4-year-old child.

B) INCORRECT:

Typically, 4-year-old children can copy a square and draw a person with several body parts. The ability to copy a triangle is not expected in a 4-year-old child and is more likely in a 5-year-old child.

C) INCORRECT:

Children who are 6 years of age or older are typically able to tie their own shoes, but 4-year-old children should not be able to perform that task.

D) INCORRECT:

Some 4-year-old children may be able to hop, but this skill may take until closer to age 5. Similarly, the ability to skip with two feet and to walk backward toe-to-heel are skills more commonly demonstrated by 5-year-old children, so an inability to do these tasks does not signal delayed development in a 4-year-old child.

E) CORRECT:

Parents are typically reliable reporters of their children’s motor development, but during well visits, the clinician should watch the child’s posture, play, and spontaneous motor function while taking the history — and then, if possible, directly observe the child using their motor skills. It is important to identify problems in coordination, fine-motor skills, and graphomotor skills to allow the earliest intervention possible.

Normal fine- and gross-motor development in a 4-year-old child includes the ability to unbutton buttons, catch a large ball, and climb stairs alternating feet.

Key learning point: A normally developing 4-year-old child can typically unbutton buttons.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy with no significant medical history is seen for a routine well-child check. His height, weight, and BMI are at the 75th percentile, and his physical examination is normal.
His parents report that he uses the toilet independently. He can speak 500 words and form 5- to 6-word sentences with complete intelligibility. He can hop on one foot two times but cannot skip, can copy a square but not a triangle, and can draw a person with two body parts but cannot count to 4. He engages in imaginative play but not group play.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this boy's care?

choices.text: Have the parents complete a specific questionnaire to screen for delays in problem-solving and in social and emotional development
Reassure the parents, and schedule a follow-up visit in one year
Refer the patient to speech therapy to address a delay in expressive language
Have the parents complete a questionnaire to screen for autism spectrum disorder
Refer the patient to physical and occupational therapy to evaluate a delay in motor development

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This child does not meet the expected milestones for cognitive and social-emotional development, so further screening should be conducted using a formal tool with documented sensitivity and specificity for identifying delays. Typically, a child this age would be expected to draw a person with at least three body parts and to count a few numbers, reaching 10 by the age of 5. Four-year-old children also typically engage in not only imaginative play (as this child does) but also group play. This child would be expected to want to play with others and to ask to play with friends if they are not around. Children develop at different rates, but if basic developmental screening milestones are not met, specific, in-depth screening should be undertaken in the area of concern.

Developmental surveillance is recommended at all well-child visits, with a standardized developmental screen for all children at 9, 18, and 24 or 30 months of age. Screening for autism spectrum disorder is recommended at ages 18 months and 24 months or if a child has any of the defining characteristics of the disorder, such as persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts; restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities; and significant functional impairment.

Any child who has developmental risks identified during surveillance screening should undergo a formal developmental screening, which is the most appropriate next step for this child. One example of a widely used standardized screening tool is the Ages and Stages Questionnaire (ASQ), which assesses for developmental delay in children between the ages of 12 months and 5.5 years. Tools such as the ASQ have been shown to be substantially more sensitive than a clinician's subjective impression in identifying developmental-behavioral problems. If the ASQ identifies concerns, the child should be referred to their local school system for comprehensive developmental evaluation. For children under 3 years of age, referral to early intervention would be appropriate.

Key learning point: A 4-year-old child who is developing normally should be able to hop on one foot two to three times, copy a square, use the toilet alone, use 500 words with complete intelligibility, draw a person with several body parts, and engage in group play.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance with follow-up in one year is not appropriate for this patient, given the concerns for possible delays in his cognitive and social-emotional development.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient is exhibiting normal verbal development with more than 500 words and the ability to form 5- to 6-word sentences; thus, referral for speech therapy is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for autism spectrum disorder is recommended at ages 18 months and 24 months or if a child has any of the defining characteristics of the disorder, such as persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts; restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities; and significant functional impairment.

E) INCORRECT:

In terms of fine-motor skills, children progress from being able to draw a circle by age 3 years to a cross by age 4 years and then eventually to a triangle. Gross-motor skills at age 4 years include climbing stairs alternating feet and, by age 5 years, hopping on one foot two to three times, which this child is already doing. Given that this patient does not exhibit any gross- or fine-motor delays, there are no indications for physical or occupational therapy at this time.

questions.text:
The mother of a 24-month-old boy expresses concern that he is not speaking as well as his same-age peers in day care. The mother’s primary language is English; the father’s is Spanish. Both languages are spoken at home.
The child began babbling at 7 months of age, spoke his first words by 15 months, and is just now putting two words together occasionally. His words are clear and understandable, but he mixes languages. His mother reports he has started to put on his own clothing and can pedal a tricycle. His medical history is unremarkable.
His height, weight, and head circumference are at the 25th percentile. The physical examination, including tympanoscopy, is normal, and he responds to simple verbal commands. He is also able to point to his nose and ears when asked.
What is the most likely diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given this child's normal examination and his ability to clearly speak and understand two languages, he is unlikely to have hearing impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Given this child's normal examination and his ability to clearly speak and understand two languages, he is unlikely to have language delay (the inability to communicate at an age-appropriate level).

C) CORRECT:

When children are exposed to two languages, their language skills tend to develop at the same pace as their monolingual peers, but they tend to initially mix the two languages, as in this case.

This patient is meeting the language and developmental milestones for his age (putting on his own clothes, combining two words, following directions, and pedaling a tricycle). His growth is within normal limits, and his physical examination does not suggest a hearing or speech disorder. His speech and overall development can continue to be monitored at his well-child visits. By 3 to 4 years of age, his English language skills should be equivalent to those of monolingual children.

Key learning point: It may take longer than expected for children raised in a bilingual environment to become fluent in both languages.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient is meeting the language and developmental milestones for his age (putting on his own clothes, combining two words, following directions, and pedaling a tricycle). His achievement of age-appropriate milestones makes global development delay unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Given this child's normal examination and his ability to clearly speak and understand two languages, he is unlikely to have speech delay (a lag or disorder in the mechanical production of sound).

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl who lives in a home where both English and Spanish are spoken is brought in for a routine well-child visit. Her parents are concerned that she has a smaller vocabulary than other children in her day-care class. Currently, she calls her parents “mami” and “papa” and says “banana” in English and “agua” in Spanish, but she understands many more words in both languages. To have her needs met, she typically points to objects and pulls her parents toward things. She has generally been healthy except for a single episode of otitis media at 9 months of age.
During the interview, she giggles with you when playing, scribbles with a crayon, gets her toy when asked verbally to do so, and is able to run down the office hallway. Her growth parameters and vital signs are normal. Physical examination is significant only for a dull, poorly mobile, non-erythematous tympanic membrane on the left.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Referral for applied behavioral analysis services
Reassurance that bilingual children often have smaller vocabularies initially
Referral to the local public school for a special education assessment
Referral to otolaryngology for placement of tympanostomy tubes
Referral to both audiology and the local early intervention program

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral for applied behavioral analysis services is appropriate for a child with suspected autism spectrum disorder. This child has reassuring social skills and demonstrates shared attention by pointing and pulling her parents to things.

B) INCORRECT:

Living in a bilingual home does not cause language delays, although children in such homes may initially mix the two languages. Merely reassuring the parents about this child's development is not appropriate, given her delayed speech and language development.

C) INCORRECT:

Local early intervention programs are appropriate for children younger than age 3, whereas school-based early intervention services are more appropriate for those aged 3 or older.

D) INCORRECT:

Referral to otolaryngology may eventually be necessary for this child if her otitis media with effusion persists. However, placement of tympanostomy tubes at this time would be premature, especially because she has only a unilateral effusion.

E) CORRECT:

This patient may have an isolated delay in speech and language development. Although she has met the gross-motor, fine-motor, and social-behavioral milestones for her age, her expressive language is delayed. The speech and language developmental domain includes receptive and expressive communication through speech and nonverbal communication.

Development of expressive communication begins with cooing, proceeds to babbling of consonant-vowel sounds at about 6 months of age, then canonical babbling (reduplicated consonant-vowel sounds) at 6 to 9 months of age, followed by first words at 9 to 15 months of age. Typically, nonverbal communication (including pointing) begins at about 9 months of age.

Around one year of age, children typically begin to use “mama,” “dada,” or another special word for their caregivers. By 18 months of age, most children increase their expressive vocabulary and try to say words in addition to “mama” or “dada” for a total of at least five words. Factors contributing to early language development include socioeconomic status, family history of language delay, and the amount of language to which a child is exposed during early life. Living in a bilingual home does not cause language delays, although children in such homes may initially mix the two languages.

By 2 years of age, a child would be expected to have close to 50 words, but this patient has an expressive vocabulary of only four words; thus, she should be referred for both an audiology evaluation and early intervention services. Targeted early intervention services have been shown in observational studies to improve educational, behavioral, and health outcomes for children with delays that are identified and addressed. Local early intervention programs are appropriate for children younger than age 3, whereas school-based early intervention services are more appropriate for those aged 3 or older.

Key learning point: A child with a possible speech and language delay should be referred to audiology and either the local early intervention program (if the child is <3 years of age) or the local public school early childhood program (if the child is ≥3 years of age).

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents for a well-child visit. His mother is concerned that his speech and language development is delayed compared with that of his peers and his older siblings at a similar age. She notes that his father had delayed language development as a child. Hearing screening in the newborn nursery was normal.
Failure to reach which one of the following milestones would confirm this mother's concern and prompt hearing screening and a referral for further evaluation and treatment?

choices.text: Knowledge of full name and address
Ability to list things in a category (e.g., animals)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ability to recite one's full name and address is a skill typically acquired around 5 years of age and is not expected of a 3-year-old child.

B) INCORRECT:

The ability to rhyme words is a skill typically acquired around 5 years of age and is not expected of a 3-year-old child.

C) INCORRECT:

Speech should be 75% intelligible at 3 years of age and fully (100%) intelligible by 4 years of age.

D) CORRECT:

Speech and language development during infancy and childhood involves reaching milestones in predictable patterns, whereby new skills build on those that have already been mastered. Infants begin expressive language through cooing and then progress to babbling, canonical babbling, and then the formation of single words. Potential causes of speech and language delay include congenital and acquired conditions such as learning and intellectual disabilities, neglect, traumatic brain injury, hearing loss, and autism spectrum disorder.

By 3 years of age, most children have a vocabulary of hundreds of words and the ability to form three- to five-word sentences. The inability to use three-word sentences is considered a red flag, meriting further assessment and evaluation for a possible speech and language delay.

Any child for whom there is a concern for speech and language delay should undergo hearing screening and receive a referral for further evaluation and management. Normal hearing screening in the newborn period does not obviate the need for hearing screening at later ages when there is delay. For children under 3 years of age, early intervention is often the first step; however, for children age 3 years and older, prompt referral to a speech-language pathologist is indicated.

Speech should be 75% intelligible at 3 years of age and fully (100%) intelligible by 4 years of age. By age 4, a child should also be able to tell a story and list items in a category, such as animals. A 3-year-old unable to do this would not be considered delayed.

Key learning point: Developmental milestones for speech and language development in a 3-year-old child include use of three- to five-word sentences, speech that is 75% intelligible, and knowledge of one's full name and age.

E) INCORRECT:

By age 4, a child should be able to list items in a category, such as animals. A 3-year-old unable to do this would not be considered delayed.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy is brought in by his mother for a well-child examination. She has no concerns about his nutrition, sleep, or safety. She reports that he can say “mama” and “dada” but has no other words. He can wave good-bye and will occasionally play peek-a-boo. He is able to sit without support but will not pull to stand and is not yet cruising. When placed in a standing position, he cannot remain standing without holding onto his mother’s hand. He can stack two blocks and feed himself pieces of fruit but is not yet able to scribble when given a crayon.
On physical examination, his growth parameters are in the 25th percentile. He is awake, alert, and interactive. His neurologic examination is unremarkable, with normal tone and reflexes in the upper and lower extremities.
In addition to having the mother complete a validated developmental assessment tool, what is the most appropriate next step for evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the mother that the child is developing normally
Screen for autism with the M-CHAT questionnaire
Refer to audiology for hearing testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Children who are developing normally can typically sit independently and pull to stand by 9 months of age and then stand independently by 12 months. Children will typically take their first independent steps closer to 15 months of age. This patient has not yet reached the gross-motor milestones expected for a 12-month-old child, which suggests a delay requiring further intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Referral to orthopedics is not necessary for this patient, given his normal physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening for autism is recommended in all children at 18 months and at 24 months. The Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers (M-CHAT) questionnaire is a validated in-office tool used to screen for autism in children aged 16 to 30 months; it is not validated for children as young as this patient (12 months). A revised form of the M-CHAT questionnaire with follow-up of concerning responses (M-CHAT-R/F) is also available.

D) CORRECT:

Children who are developing normally can typically sit independently and pull to stand by 9 months of age and then stand independently by 12 months. Children will typically take their first independent steps closer to 15 months of age. This patient has not yet reached the gross-motor milestones expected for a 12-month-old child, which suggests a delay requiring further intervention.

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends using a validated screening tool to assess the development of all children at ages 9 months, 18 months, and 30 months — or at any point when the caregiver or clinician has a concern. In this case, the clinician has cause to be concerned about a possible developmental delay, so the mother should be asked to complete a validated screening questionnaire in the office, and the child should be referred to early intervention services because concern for delay has already been noted.

Key learning point: A 12-month-old child with normal gross-motor development should be able to pull to stand and stand well independently.

E) INCORRECT:

Referral to audiology would be appropriate if there were concern for speech delay or hearing. This patient has normal communication skills, saying “mama” and “dada” and waving.

questions.text: The parents of an 18-month-old boy express concern about his language development because he does not seem to be talking as much as his older sister did at the same age. The parents report that he uses “mama” and “dada” appropriately. He also says "ball" and a form of his sister’s name. On examination, he is not found to have any significant sensory deficits. Which one of the following additional pieces of this child's history would be most consistent with a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder?

choices.text: Not being able to dress himself
Not starting to walk independently until 15 months of age
Sleeping through the night and taking two naps during the day
Not pointing at objects that he wants
Not signing any additional words such as “more”

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gross-motor skills (such as walking), fine-motor skills (such as dressing oneself), and sleeping patterns do not define ASD.

B) INCORRECT:

Gross-motor skills (such as walking), fine-motor skills (such as dressing oneself), and sleeping patterns do not define ASD.

C) INCORRECT:

Gross-motor skills (such as walking), fine-motor skills (such as dressing oneself), and sleeping patterns do not define ASD.

D) CORRECT:

Speech and language delays are often seen in autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and are usually accompanied by additional deficits in social reciprocity and often by repetitive interests or behaviors. Young children with ASD often lack what is called "joint attention" — where they show objects to other people or engage the attention of other people in order to share experiences. At 12 to 14 months of age, children typically begin pointing to objects, to request them or to draw their parent’s attention to what they find interesting. By 16 months, a typically developing child will point at an interesting object and then look back and forth between the parent and the object to make sure the parent is seeing it. If this child were not pointing out objects to his parents by 18 months, it would be concerning for a delay in social skills and also for the possibility of ASD, given his additional language delay.

Key learning point: The skill group that is most often deficient in an 18-month-old child with autism spectrum disorder is a deficit in social skills.

E) INCORRECT:

As part of expressive language development, some children will learn signs such as “more” in which the fingers, with the thumb held underneath, are brought together. Although signs may be considered when assessing a toddler’s expressive vocabulary, lack of signs is not indicative of autism or language delay per se.
questions.hint: An 18-month-old child should speak between 10 and 20 words and be able to link two or more words into a recognizable sentence. This child has not yet reached these milestones, signifying a speech and language delay.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for a well-child visit. The parents report that she has been crying excessively since the last visit and are concerned that she is not well. They say that she used to be calm when she was left alone, but over the past week, she starts to cry whenever they leave the room. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she coos “ma” and “da.” She is able to independently get into a seated position, and passes a teddy from one hand to the other. She begins to cry when the provider picks her up. The anterior fontanelle is soft and the remainder of the examination does not show any abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reactive attachment disorder manifests with an inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior towards caretakers without seeking comfort when distressed. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures, which is not consistent with reactive attachment disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) usually manifests with detachment and inability or difficulty to form relationships. This patient, however, cries when her parents leave the room, indicating a strong attachment and anxiety of separation of attachment figures. Moreover, patients with ASD typically present with other findings such as abnormal language development and stereotypical patterns of behavior (e.g., hand flapping, adverse response to sounds), none of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Infantile colic manifests with episodes of crying in otherwise healthy and thriving infants, which is seen here. However, crying in infantile colic is not associated with the absence of attachment figures, or the presence of strangers. Moreover, infantile colic typically resolves spontaneously by 3–4 months of age.

D) CORRECT:

This 9-month-old child presents with milestones that are appropriate for her age. Her crying pattern is consistent with stranger anxiety (crying when picked up by strangers) and separation anxiety (crying when her parents leave the room), both of which are typical and normal social behaviors in children of this age. See “Developmental milestones in infants” table.

E) INCORRECT:

This infant shows no signs or symptoms suggestive of physical child abuse (e.g., injuries at different stages of healing). Infants who are subject to sexual child abuse may present with normal physical examination findings or with findings restricted to genital and anal areas, which can easily be overseen. Sexual child abuse should be considered in children with recurrent urinary tract infections and behavioral changes. This patient's presentation, however, is not suggestive of sexual child abuse or other types of child abuse (e.g., child neglect).
questions.hint: This 9-month old child presents with the appropriate gross motor skills (able to independently get into a seated position), fine motor skills (transfers objects from one hand to the other), and language milestones (cooing “ma” and “da”) for her age.

questions.text: A 4-month-old girl presents for a well-child visit. She is breastfed and is at the 75th percentile for weight and length and the 50th percentile for head circumference. She sleeps for 10 hours each night and takes one or two naps each day. Which one of the following examination findings would indicate the need for further developmental evaluation of this infant?

choices.text: Inability to transfer a toy from one hand to the other
Inability to roll supine to prone
Requiring trunk support to sit up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a 4-month-old infant will typically grasp for an object when it is presented to them, they do not develop the ability to transfer objects from one hand to the other until a few months later.

B) INCORRECT:

Children typically develop shyness around unfamiliar people (“stranger shyness”) around 9 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants do not typically begin to roll from supine to prone or respond to their name until closer to 6 months of age, and a child would not be considered delayed if they could not do these tasks at 4 months.

D) CORRECT:

Infants develop at differing speeds, following similar patterns of milestone acquisition over time. Each well-child visit provides an opportunity to elicit parental concerns about development. A careful history of developmental progress should be taken in order to identify children at risk who should be referred for early intervention or further evaluation.

A 4-month-old infant who is developing normally would be expected to have reached the following milestones:

• Gross motor: Sits steady when you are supporting their trunk and will not have head lag when pulled from a prone position to sitting
• Fine motor: Uses their arm to swing at toys, grasps a toy when it is placed in their hand, and spontaneously brings their hands to their mouth
• Social-emotional: Smiles spontaneously at pleasurable sights or sounds and chuckles
• Language: Turns their head toward the sound of a caregiver’s voice and makes sounds back to the caregiver

Infants typically develop a social smile by 2 months of age and by 4 months should smile spontaneously, especially at people, and may begin to chuckle and even laugh at pleasurable things.

Key learning point: A 4-month-old infant who witnesses a pleasurable sight or person should be able to smile spontaneously.

E) INCORRECT:

A 4-month-old infant who is developing normally would be expected to have reached the following milestones:

• Gross motor: Sits steady when you are supporting their trunk and will not have head lag when pulled from a prone position to sitting.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is seen for a routine well-child evaluation. Her father expresses no concerns about her development. Review of her growth chart demonstrates steady growth along the 75th percentile for height, weight, and head circumference. She says “mama,” “dada,” and “baby.” She can stand well and take a few independent steps. She holds a crayon and can dump things out of a container. As you leave the room, she waves bye-bye. Which one of the following additional tasks should this patient be able to complete?

choices.text: Build a tower of three to four cubes
Pick up a small piece of food with a pincer grasp
Climb on and off a couch or chair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a 12-month-old child may hold a crayon, spontaneous scribbling is typically not observed until closer to 18 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

The ability to stack two small objects is not obtained until approximately 15 months of age, and building a tower of 4 to 6 objects does not come until later, when the child is older than 2 years of age.

C) INCORRECT:

Turning a doorknob or unscrewing a lid is a task for a 2.5-year-old child.

D) CORRECT:

In terms of motor development, a 12-month-old child should be able to pick up small pieces of food using a mature pincer grasp and drink from a cup without a lid when it is held for them.

Key learning point: In a typically developing child, the ability to pick up small pieces of food with a mature pincer grasp is seen at age 12 months.

E) INCORRECT:

The ability to climb on or off a couch or chair is not acquired until closer to 18 months of age.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office because her mother is concerned that she has been talking to an imaginary friend for 2 months. The child calls her friend 'Lucy' and says “Lucy is my best friend”. The child has multiple conversations and plays with 'Lucy' throughout the day. The girl attends preschool regularly. She can hold a pencil between the first two fingers and the thumb, tells stories, and can hop on one foot. Her parents are currently divorcing. The child's father has a history of illicit drug use. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The mother is concerned about whether the child is acting out because of the divorce. Which of the following is the most appropriate next best step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A number of drugs such as cocaine, ecstasy, amphetamines, lysergic acid diethylamide, and phencyclidine have been associated with hallucinations in children (e.g., following accidental ingestion). Since this girl's father has a history of drug abuse, unintentional contact with these substances should be considered. However, symptoms would typically have an acute onset, would not last for two months as in this girl, and would be different in character (e.g., perception of unusual colors).

B) INCORRECT:

Intracranial neoplasms can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including hallucinations. However, hallucinations as a primary symptom in the absence of other signs of a tumor, such as focal symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure, are very rare.

C) INCORRECT:

Child Protective Services (CPS) should be informed if there are signs of abuse or neglect of a minor. Signs of abuse and neglect can be subtle and history findings of parental drug use should certainly raise concern for the child's well-being. Although patients, particularly following sexual abuse, can develop hallucinations, these hallucinations commonly cause distress rather than comfort as in this patient. Additionally, this patient's age-appropriate milestones, the absence of signs of physical abuse, and the fact that she attends preschool regularly make child maltreatment less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A psychiatric consult would be indicated if an underlying psychiatric condition was suspected. While a variety of psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia or posttraumatic stress disorder can present with hallucinations, they are rare during childhood and more commonly associated with negative hallucinations (e.g., cause fear or distress). Additionally, unlike this girl, patients often show signs of abnormal development (e.g., delayed milestones).

E) CORRECT:

Imaginary friends are relatively common in preschoolers such as this girl and occur as part of normal development. Children typically get along with these friends (e.g., consider them “their best friend”) and the imaginary figures do not cause any distress or impaired functioning. Parents should be reassured. Further evaluation is only indicated if the imaginary friends persist beyond early school age, or if the child's general behavior or development changes.

Stress factors such as the parent's divorce can cause various behavioral responses in different age groups. Preschoolers such as this girl often display magical thinking and may believe that their actions caused the divorce. They can subsequently develop unusual or odd behaviors in the hope of reconciling their parents. Parents should be advised to reassure the child that their actions had no influence on the decision to get a divorce. A counselor can assist if problems persist.
questions.hint: This patient's gross motor (hops on one foot), fine motor (tripod pencil grasp), and language (tells stories) developmental milestones are all appropriate for her age.

questions.text:
A 13-month-old girl is brought to the office for a well-child examination. There is no family history of serious illness. She cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position. She can pick an object between her thumb and index finger but cannot feed herself using a spoon. She comes when called by name, is willing to play with a ball, and looks for it after being hidden. She cries if she does not see her parents in the same room as her. She babbles. She is at 50th percentile for height and weight. Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of her development?



Fine motor
Gross motor
Language
Social skills



A
Delayed
Normal
Delayed
Normal


B
Normal
Delayed
Normal
Delayed


C
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
Normal


D
Normal
Normal
Delayed
Delayed


E
Normal
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate social skills development (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) and delayed language development (i.e., only babbles). However, she cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position, which suggests delayed gross motor skills development. In addition, her fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp) is appropriate for her age.

B) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp), and delayed gross motor skills development (i.e., cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position). However, she only babbles, which suggests delayed language development. In addition, her social skills (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) are appropriate for her age.

C) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate social skills development (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) and delayed gross motor skills development (i.e., cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position). However, she only babbles, which suggests delayed language development. In addition, her fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp) is appropriate for her age.

D) INCORRECT:

This 13-month-old girl shows appropriate fine motor skills development (i.e., pincer grasp) and delayed language development (i.e., only babbles). However, she cannot pull herself to stand from a sitting position, which suggests delayed gross motor skills development. In addition, her social skills (i.e., engages in play, and looks for hidden objects) are appropriate for her age.

E) CORRECT:

By the age of 12 months, most children can pull themselves to a stand, walk with support, and use specific sounds to refer to a particular person (e.g., call the mother “mama” and the father “dada”). This child only has the gross motor development and speech development of a 9-month-old (sitting without support, babbling). Her fine motor skills development (pincer grasp) and social development (e.g., willingness to engage in play by giving objects, looking for hidden objects, separation anxiety) are appropriate for a 13-month-old child. The ability to feed oneself with a spoon is only expected by the age of 2 years.

See “Developmental milestones in infancy” table.

Key learning point: At 13 months, normal milestones include pincer grasp and social play, but inability to pull to stand or use words indicates delayed gross motor and language development.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office for a well-child examination. She can climb up and down the stairs and can pedal a tricycle. She uses a spoon to feed herself but cannot yet use a fork. She speaks in three-word sentences that most people can understand and says her first name when asked. She is selfish while playing with children of her age and often throws tantrums. She can put on her own shoes and socks. She does not tolerate separation from her parents. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of her development?



Gross motor
Fine motor
Language
Social skills



A
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
Normal


B
Normal
Delayed
Normal
Delayed


C
Delayed
Normal
Normal
Delayed


D
Normal
Normal
Delayed
Delayed


E
Normal
Delayed
Delayed
Normal
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) and delayed fine motor skill development (i.e., only feeding herself using a spoon). However, she has strong separation anxiety and selfish, self-centered behavior, both of which suggest delayed social development. In addition, her gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) is appropriate for a 3-year-old.

B) CORRECT:

This 3-year-old has appropriate language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) and gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes). By the age of 3 years, most children can also use a fork, engage in group play, share toys with other children, and have minimal separation anxiety (since they begin to develop a drive for independence). Therefore, this child has delayed fine motor skills and social development.

See “Developmental milestones in childhood” table.

C) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) and delayed social development (i.e., strong separation anxiety, self-centered behavior). However, she can only feed herself using a spoon, which suggests delayed fine motor skill development. In addition, her gross motor skills (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) are appropriate for a 3-year-old.

D) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) and delayed social development (i.e., strong separation anxiety, self-centered behavior). However, she can only feed herself using a spoon, which suggests delayed fine motor skill development. In addition, her language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) is appropriate for a 3-year-old.

E) INCORRECT:

This 3-year-old shows appropriate gross motor skill development (i.e., riding a tricycle, climbing up and down the stairs, independently putting on some clothes) and delayed fine motor skill development (i.e., only using a spoon to feed herself). However, she has strong separation anxiety and selfish, self-centered behavior, both of which suggest delayed social development. In addition, her language development (i.e., speech is understood by most people, says her first name when asked) is appropriate for a 3-year-old.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine visit. He is often seen pretending to run a store or a classroom with his friends. According to his mother, he speaks in sentences of four to five words and follows two-step commands. He draws a person with a circle for the head and lines for arms and legs. He removes his shirt by himself but needs help with buttons.
Which of the following abilities is most consistent with his current developmental level?

choices.text: Telling a brief story about a recent event

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reading simple three-letter words requires phonemic awareness and decoding skills, which typically develop closer to age 5 or later. The child's current skills, such as imaginative play and basic drawing, align with typical four-year-old milestones, indicating that formal reading skills are not yet expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Neat writing of a name requires fine motor coordination typically seen in children closer to ages 5 or 6. At age 4, children are developing pre-writing skills and may begin forming letters, but neat and legible writing is beyond their expected developmental level.

C) CORRECT:

By age 4, children typically develop the ability to tell brief stories about recent events. This skill involves integrating language, cognitive, and social abilities, allowing them to use memory, sequencing, and expressive language to narrate experiences. The child's ability to speak in sentences and follow multi-step commands supports this narrative development. Imaginative play further enhances cognitive growth and symbolic thought, reinforcing storytelling skills.

Key learning point: At age 4, children typically can tell short stories, engage in role-playing, draw figures with a head, hands, and feet, and undress themselves.

D) INCORRECT:

Fastening shoelaces requires advanced fine motor coordination and planning, skills that usually develop around ages 5 to 6. The child's current abilities, such as drawing simple figures and following two-step commands, align with typical preschool milestones, not the more complex task of independent shoelace fastening.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl is brought to the Outpatient Clinic by her mother for a check-up. She pulls to stand and cruises along furniture but has not yet attempted to walk independently. She babbles, using 'mama' and 'dada' to refer to her parents, but produces no other words. She picks up small food pieces with a neat pincer grasp, gestures for objects she wants, and turns toward her name. Her mother is concerned about potential developmental delays. Growth parameters are at the 50th percentile.
Which of the following developmental milestones is most likely to appear next?

choices.text: Using a spoon to feed herself with minimal spilling
Combining two words to form short phrases

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Using a spoon with minimal spilling typically emerges around 15–18 months. At 12 months, children focus more on gross motor skills like walking independently. Spoon use requires advanced fine motor control and hand-eye coordination, which mature after the development of a pincer grasp.

B) INCORRECT:

Running without falling is a later milestone that follows independent walking. It requires well-established balance and coordination. Since the child has not yet taken independent steps, running is premature and not the immediate next milestone.

C) CORRECT:

At 12 months, children typically pull to stand and cruise along furniture, which are precursors to independent walking. Walking independently usually develops by 15 months as balance, strength, and coordination mature. This progression involves rapid development of neural pathways and musculoskeletal systems, enabling the transition from supported movements to independent steps. The concurrent development of fine motor skills, language, and social communication highlights the integrated nature of developmental milestones during infancy.

Key learning point: Walking with one hand held, saying a few words besides 'mama' and 'dada', and using an unassisted pincer grasp are developmental milestones typically seen around 12 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Two-word combinations usually emerge around 18 to 24 months, as toddlers expand their expressive language skills. At 12 months, infants typically use single words or babbled approximations, reflecting age-appropriate language development.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old mother brings her 2-month-old infant to a routine visit. She is concerned because the baby does not attempt to reach for objects during play. On observation, the infant smiles when greeted, follows a brightly colored rattle smoothly across midline, and coos occasionally. Head control is fair, but the baby cannot lift the chest when prone.
Which of the following best describes the most appropriate conclusion regarding this infant’s age-appropriate development?

choices.text: Should be able to reach for objects by this age
Consistent with normal social and visual milestones for a 2-month-old
Should already be rolling over from prone to supine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

At 2 months, infants are expected to engage in social smiling, visual tracking, and cooing, not reaching for objects. Reaching requires refined hand-eye coordination, typically developing around 4 to 5 months. Expecting a 2-month-old to reach for objects is premature, as this skill emerges later in normal motor development.

B) INCORRECT:

The infant's ability to follow a brightly colored rattle smoothly across the midline indicates normal visual tracking for a 2-month-old. Smooth pursuit eye movements are expected at this age, confirming normal ocular motor function. The lack of reaching for objects should not be confused with visual tracking delay, as reaching develops later.

C) CORRECT:

At 2 months, infants typically exhibit a social smile, cooing, and the ability to visually track objects across the midline, all of which are observed in this infant. These behaviors indicate normal social and visual development for this age. While head control is developing, reaching for objects and lifting the chest when prone are milestones expected in later months. The infant's current abilities align with the expected developmental profile for a 2-month-old, confirming appropriate social and visual milestones.

Key learning point: At approximately 8 weeks, infants typically smile in response to social interactions and can follow moving objects 180 degrees, but they do not yet reach for objects.

D) INCORRECT:

Rolling from prone to supine usually develops around 4 months of age. At 2 months, infants are in the early stages of motor development, focusing on social smiling, cooing, and visual tracking. The inability to lift the chest when prone is typical for this age, indicating that rolling over is not yet expected.

questions.text:
A 17-month-old boy is brought to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine visit. He began walking on his own at 14 months and now walks quickly around the house. He can stack two blocks and produces random marks on paper with crayons. He follows simple one-step commands and uses several single words to communicate. His mother is worried that he cannot jump or copy shapes yet. Vital signs and physical examination are normal.
Which of the following findings would best indicate age-appropriate motor development at 18 months?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Copying a circle requires advanced fine motor coordination and visual-motor integration, typically developing around 3 years of age. At 18 months, children engage in non-specific scribbling, reflecting emerging fine motor skills. The precision needed to copy shapes like circles exceeds the capabilities of an 18-month-old.

B) INCORRECT:

At 18 months, toddlers usually climb stairs with assistance, placing both feet on each step. Alternating feet requires advanced balance and coordination, typically developing closer to 2 years of age. This skill is beyond the expected motor development for an 18-month-old.

C) CORRECT:

At 18 months, children typically demonstrate improved fine motor skills, such as stacking three to four blocks. This ability reflects enhanced hand-eye coordination and spatial awareness, building on the earlier milestone of stacking two blocks. This progression is consistent with the developmental trajectory at this age, where toddlers show advancing skills in both fine and gross motor domains, as well as emerging problem-solving abilities.

Key learning point: By 18 months, children typically can walk independently, throw a ball overhand, draw a straight line, and stack blocks, indicating advanced motor skill development.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutting paper with scissors requires a mature pincer grasp and bilateral hand coordination, skills typically mastered closer to 2–3 years of age. At 18 months, children engage in simpler fine motor activities, such as scribbling and stacking blocks, rather than complex tasks like cutting paper.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who is concerned that she cannot copy a square. The child can ride a tricycle independently, recognizes and states her name and age, and can put on most of her clothing with minimal assistance. She speaks in three- to four-word sentences. Physical examination is normal, and growth parameters are within normal limits.
Which of the following statements best describes the child's developmental status?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The child demonstrates age-appropriate social skills, such as recognizing her name and age, using three- to four-word sentences, and independently managing tasks like riding a tricycle and dressing. These abilities indicate normal social interaction and communication patterns for a three-year-old.

B) CORRECT:

At three years of age, children typically manifest gross motor skills such as riding a tricycle. Fine motor skills at this age do not yet include copying complex shapes like squares. Language milestones include speaking in three- to four-word sentences and stating basic personal information, such as name and age. Self-care skills, like dressing with minimal assistance, further demonstrate coordinated progression across developmental domains. These milestones confirm that the child's development aligns with age-appropriate expectations.

Key learning point: At 3 years old, children typically can ride a tricycle, know their name, age, and gender, and can dress with some assistance, but may have difficulty copying a square.

C) INCORRECT:

The child can ride a tricycle independently, a key gross motor milestone for a 3-year-old. This ability indicates appropriate balance, coordination, and lower extremity strength, showing that her gross motor skills are within normal developmental expectations for her age.

D) INCORRECT:

The inability to copy a square is not expected at age three, as children typically engage in simpler fine motor activities like scribbling or copying a circle. The child demonstrates appropriate fine motor skills through activities like dressing with minimal assistance, indicating intact basic fine motor skills.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy is brought by his mother to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine check-up. She mentions that he can roll from supine to prone and sits briefly when propped on his arms. The infant coos and babbles often, is generally playful, and has no concerning medical history. Examination shows normal growth parameters and no abnormal findings.
Which motor skill is most appropriate for a typically developing 6-month-old infant to exhibit?

choices.text: Sitting unassisted in a tripod position
Taking steps while holding one hand

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulling to stand generally emerges between 8 and 10 months, requiring strength and balance not typically present at 6 months. At this age, infants are expected to roll over and sit with support, not pull to stand.

B) CORRECT:

At 6 months, infants typically achieve the ability to sit in a tripod position, using their arms for support. This milestone reflects developing core strength and neuromuscular coordination, indicating progress toward independent sitting. The tripod position is a transitional stage that precedes fully unsupported sitting, which usually occurs later in infancy. This skill is indicative of healthy neuromuscular development and aligns with typical motor progression for this age.

Key learning point: At 6 months, infants typically can sit in the tripod position and roll over, but they have not yet developed the pincer grasp, which usually appears around 9 months.

C) INCORRECT:

The pincer grasp, involving thumb and index finger coordination, typically develops around 9 to 10 months. At 6 months, infants usually demonstrate early fine motor skills like reaching and using a palmar grasp, not the refined pincer grasp.

D) INCORRECT:

Taking steps with support, or cruising, usually develops around 9 to 12 months. At 6 months, infants lack the postural control and leg strength needed for coordinated stepping, focusing instead on skills like rolling and supported sitting.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the Pediatric Clinic by his parents for a routine well-child visit. They report he consistently asks questions such as “Why?” and “Where?” He speaks in short sentences of 3–4 words and follows two-step commands like “Pick up your toy and put it in the box.” They add that strangers sometimes struggle to understand him. Physical examination is normal, and prior hearing screening was normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer for immediate speech-language pathology assessment
Order neuroimaging to rule out structural abnormalities
Reassure the parents that his communication is appropriate for his age

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate referral to speech-language pathology is not warranted as the child's language development, including forming 3- to 4-word sentences and following two-step commands, is typical for his age. His questioning indicates normal cognitive engagement, and prior normal hearing screening supports that speech is not impacted by sensory deficits.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging is not indicated as the child shows no signs of neurologic deficits, regression, or seizures. His language development, including forming short sentences and following commands, is within the expected range for his age, and there are no red flags suggesting structural brain anomalies.

C) INCORRECT:

A repeat hearing evaluation is unnecessary as the child had a normal prior hearing screening. His ability to follow two-step commands indicates intact auditory processing. Occasional difficulty with pronunciation is typical for his age and does not suggest hearing impairment.

D) CORRECT:

At age 3, children typically form 3- to 4-word sentences, follow two-step commands, and ask questions like 'Why?' and 'Where?', indicating normal language development. His speech may be less clear to strangers, which is common at this age as articulation skills are still developing. The normal physical examination and prior normal hearing screening further support that his language abilities are age-appropriate. Reassurance aligns with developmental guidelines recognizing variability in early speech intelligibility.

Key learning point: A 3-year-old child should be able to speak in sentences, be understood by strangers 75% of the time, ask questions, and follow 2-part commands, indicating normal language development for age.

questions.text:
A 5-month-old boy is brought to a well-child visit. His mother is concerned that he cannot roll from his back onto his stomach. He can roll from his stomach onto his back and sits with support. He visually tracks objects across midline, babbles spontaneously, and reaches for toys placed at his side. Neurologic examination, muscle tone, and reflexes are normal. Growth parameters are at the 50th percentile.
Which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion regarding his development?

choices.text: Requires immediate referral for early intervention services
Likely congenital muscular disorder necessitating imaging
Abnormal gross motor development needing further evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

At 5 months, infants typically roll from stomach to back, with rolling from back to stomach developing closer to 6 months. Sitting with support, visual tracking across midline, spontaneous babbling, and reaching for toys are appropriate for this age. Normal neurologic examination, muscle tone, reflexes, and growth parameters further confirm that this infant's development aligns with expected milestones.

Key learning point: At 6 months of age, infants typically develop the ability to roll from supine to prone position as part of their gross motor skills development.

B) INCORRECT:

The infant's ability to roll from stomach to back, sit with support, visually track objects, and babble indicates satisfactory progress. The absence of rolling from back to stomach, expected closer to 6 months, does not warrant immediate referral for early intervention services.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital muscular disorders present with hypotonia, abnormal muscle strength, and altered reflexes, which are absent in this infant. His normal neurologic examination and age-appropriate milestones do not suggest a neuromuscular disorder, making imaging unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants usually roll from prone to supine by 4 months and from supine to prone closer to 6 months. This child demonstrates age-appropriate gross motor skills, normal neurologic findings, and other developmental milestones, indicating no need for further evaluation.

questions.text: During a 12-month visit, a mother reports her child stands unassisted, waves goodbye, but uses no words. Which milestone is typically expected at this age?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Two-word phrases typically emerge around 15 to 18 months, not at 12 months. At 12 months, children are expected to say single words like 'mama' or 'dada.' The ability to combine words into phrases develops later.

B) INCORRECT:

Three-word sentences are a more advanced milestone, usually developing closer to 2 to 3 years of age. At 12 months, children typically produce single words and rely on nonverbal communication, not full sentences.

C) CORRECT:

By 12 months, infants typically begin using at least one meaningful word, such as 'mama' or 'dada,' indicating a shift from babbling to verbal communication. This milestone marks the beginning of expressive language development, complementing gestures like waving goodbye. While more complex language skills, such as two-word phrases, develop later, the emergence of a single meaningful word at this age is a key indicator of typical speech and language progression.

Key learning point: Most children begin to say a few words by around 12 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants usually start using meaningful words by 10 to 12 months, often saying 'mama' or 'dada' with specific reference. The absence of meaningful words until 18 months does not align with typical developmental milestones, as early word production reflects early language development.

questions.text:
A 10-month-old boy is brought to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine checkup. His parents report that he can sit unsupported, crawl, and pull to stand. He babbles using repetitive consonants and often turns when his name is called. He can pass objects between hands but typically grabs small items using a raking motion. On physical examination, he eagerly watches toys and tries to reach them but does not yet pick up smaller pieces.
